Second, to continue to invest in technology, so that the SPF can keep up with the latest threats, and deal with them effectively. Today, the public's trust in the SPF remains high. The SPF has also invested heavily in technology, and developed new capabilities. From expanding Police camera coverage and analytics, and harnessing unmanned systems as well as countering threats from them, to the use of artificial intelligence to fight scams, the SPF has been pushing technological boundaries. This has enabled our lean Force to keep crime rates low, solve crime swiftly, and hence secure the trust and confidence of Singaporeans. The Parliamentary Motion to commemorate SPF200 in 2021 was a significant milestone for the SPF. We thank PM and the Parliament of Singapore for recognising the SPF as a world-class agency and SPF officers' contributions in safeguarding Singapore. The SPF would like to thank PM for the trust and support that PM has given to the SPF. The SPF will continue to strive for the highest level of operational excellence and professionalism by upholding our core values of Courage, Loyalty, Integrity, and Fairness. Read more on (link in bio)

caption: - "" Step back in time to the launch of the Neighbourhood Police Centre (NPC) system in 1997, pioneered by Queenstown Neighbourhood Centre. The NPCs served as one-stop police centres and brought wider range of police services to the community. It allowed the Police to work in, with and through the community via the community safety and security programmes.In 2012, the Community Policing System was introduced to further strengthen the partnership with the community. The NPCs were restructured to include the Community Policing Unit and Crime Strike Force to encourage joint ownership and responsibility with the community countering terrorism and fighting crime. Technology was harnessed as a force multiplier and the Neighbourhood Police Posts were enhanced to provide the community with round-the-clock access to automated services.We will continue to enhance police-community partnership to keep Singapore safe and secure every day.singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

cleaned_caption: Step back in time to the launch of the Neighbourhood Police Centre (NPC) system in 1997, pioneered by Queenstown Neighbourhood Centre. The NPCs served as one-stop police centres and brought a wider range of police services to the community. It allowed the Police to work in, with, and through the community via the community safety and security programmes. In 2012, the Community Policing System was introduced to further strengthen the partnership with the community. The NPCs were restructured to include the Community Policing Unit and Crime Strike Force to encourage joint ownership and responsibility with the community in countering terrorism and fighting crime. Technology was harnessed as a force multiplier and the Neighbourhood Police Posts were enhanced to provide the community with round-the-clock access to automated services. We will continue to enhance police-community partnership to keep Singapore safe and secure every day.

caption: Join us at The Star Vista, 13th April, this Saturday from 10am-8pm, in celebration of the 75 years of women in policing! This event commemorates the accomplishments and contributions of both past and present generations of female police officers. Come and join us for hands-on sessions at the weapon displays, and enjoy live performances by the Women Police Pipes & Drums and a special all-women combo band. Be sure to stay for the demonstrations by various units such as the Ground Response Force, Emergency Response Team, and the Security Command.Psst! Keep your eyes peeled for our exclusive collectibles too! See you there!

caption: () On 26 October 2023, off-duty SI Alif Rashid spotted a boy in his primary school uniform loitering at a HDB void deck near a supermarket in Punggol in the late evening. As school dismissals are usually in the early afternoon, Alif sensed that something was amiss, and he decided to approach the boy. The boy shared that he had lost his way and could not find the way home.SI Alif noticed that the boy had a phone with him, but the battery was flat. He offered to charge his phone so that the boy could contact his family. In the meantime, he bought food and drinks for the boy as he did not have any food since early afternoon. After SI Alif successfully turned the boys phone on, he noticed that there were more than 5 missed calls from various numbers. Immediately, he contacted one of the numbers, which belonged to the boys grandfather.Over the phone, the boys grandfather told SI Alif that they had been looking for him for the past few hours and they were very worried. SI Alif then informed the boys grandfather that he is a police officer and that he approached the boy as he sensed that something was off. SI Alif waited with the boy until his family reunited with him at the void deck.After the incident, one of the boys family members wrote to the Police to compliment SI Alif, I dont know how to thank the officer.. He even buy food and offer care until my daughter came to fetch my grandson. I would like to recommend this officer for his good Samaritans deed..As a parent, I can understand how the boys family felt when they could not reach him for hours. I am happy to be able to do a small part to help to reunite the boy with his family, said SI Alif. singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday
cleaned_caption: On 26 October 2023, off-duty SI spotted a boy in his primary school uniform loitering at a HDB void deck near a supermarket in Punggol in the late evening. As school dismissals are usually in the early afternoon, SI sensed that something was amiss and decided to approach the boy. The boy shared that he had lost his way and could not find the way home. SI noticed that the boy had a phone with him, but the battery was flat. He offered to charge his phone so that the boy could contact his family. In the meantime, he bought food and drinks for the boy as he did not have any food since early afternoon. After SI successfully turned the boy's phone on, he noticed that there were more than 5 missed calls from various numbers. Immediately, he contacted one of the numbers, which belonged to the boy's grandfather. Over the phone, the grandfather told SI that they had been looking for him for the past few hours and they were very worried. SI then informed the grandfather that he is a police officer and that he approached the boy as he sensed that something was off. SI waited with the boy until his family reunited with him at the void deck. After the incident, one of the boy's family members wrote to the Police to compliment SI, expressing gratitude for his actions. As a parent, SI can understand how the boy's family felt when they could not reach him for hours. He expressed happiness to be able to do a small part to help reunite the boy with his family. #singaporepoliceforce #safeguardingeveryday

caption: From 1 April 2024, the Traffic Police (TP) will progressively and dynamically activate the speed enforcement function in Red Light Cameras (RLCs) island-wide to improve motorists behaviour. The RLCs are painted in orange and white and are accompanied by warning signs placed before the RLCs stating, Traffic Police Camera Zone, with the road speed limit sign above it.This activation is driven by an increase in the number of speeding-related fatal accidents year-on-year, and motorists speeding at locations where they think there is no enforcement. TP would like to urge motorists not to speed and to abide by traffic rules. TP will continue to take enforcement action against errant motorists. Remember, road safety is a shared responsibility!SingaporePoliceForce Safeguardingeveryday UseYourRoadSense

caption: : () I'm SGT Lim Wee Ern, a GRF officer from Bukit Merah East Neighbourhood Police Centre (NPC).As GRF officers, we respond to '999' calls and conduct patrols to prevent, deter and detect crime.On the ground, we face dynamic situations which sometimes can take a 180-degree turn within seconds for the better or for the worse. Thankfully, we undergo rigorous training regularly to equip ourselves to handle such situations professionally. Our top priority in such situations is always to ensure the safety of all parties involved, and if use of force is required, we will apply it proportionately to resolve the incident effectively and restore peace.I enjoy my job as a GRF officer. It gives me the opportunity to engage and interact with members of the public to find out how we can help improve the safety and security of the community, and it gives me a profound sense of accomplishment and satisfaction when I am able to assist someone in need of our help. SPFInFocus singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

caption: informed, stay safe! Police is a mobile app, with a focus on providing the latest Police news and crime prevention advisories.Its core functions include quick access to emergency functions, updated Police news and appeals, and Police e-services. Users can also obtain useful information on our community programmes and recruitment campaigns.Volunteers from the Citizens on Patrol (COP) scheme use the Citizens on Patrol Volunteer Module within the app to manage their volunteering activities, such as organising patrols and tracking patrol hours.singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

caption: The SPFs In-Situ Reaction Team (IRT) from the Protective Security Command is a specialized unit tasked with providing high-visibility police patrol and swift response to public security threats.They are highly trained and equipped with the necessary equipment and tactics to handle diverse situations.The IRT officers work closely with officers from other SPF units to maintain public safety and security in Singapore.Photos by: Naveen Rajsingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

caption: Did you know that the Singapore Police Force (SPF) Band is the oldest band in Singapore? Established in 1925, the SPF band boasts a rich heritage and is renowned for its wide repertoire of music ranging from popular favourites, big band, ethnic music of Southeast Asia to the more serious classical transcriptions. Besides encompassing a host of ensembles such as the SPF Big Band, Concert Band, Police Quintet, and the Brass Quintet, the band also has the distinction of being the only service band in Singapore that is complemented by bagpipes and drums, known as the Women Police Pipes & Drums. Earlier in February 2024, the SPF Band, together with Maestro Joost Chistiaan Flach from the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts treated the audience to a multi-sensory midday feast at the Home Team Academy! Catch the SPF Band in action this coming Saturday, 16 March 2024, 5.30pm at VivoCity Amphitheatre Level 3! All event proceeds will be donated to charity. singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

caption: " Located at Mount Pleasant, the Old Police Academy (OPA) was established in 1929 and was the first permanent institution to professionally train police officers until its closure in 2005. In the present day, police training is conducted at the Home Team Academy in Choa Chu Kang. For officers that trained in the OPA, some architectural icons include the Old Drill Shed, Parade Square and Swimming Pool. In particular, the Old Drill Shed was an iconic part of the OPA, as it was utilised to conduct trainings and doubled up as an event space to host ceremonies. In the future, the OPA site would be developed into a housing estate with the heritage elements incorporated. singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

caption: : Im SGT Si Min, an Investigation Officer (IO) from the Central Police Division.As an IO, I gather evidence, analyse leads, interview victims, witnesses and suspects to ensure that reported crimes are investigated thoroughly.Every case is unique and it requires unwavering perseverance to leave no stone unturned in our investigations to bring the truth to light. There is fulfilment in what I do, especially when I bring closure to the victims and see justice being served to the perpetrators.However, as with every job, there are always challenges. Sometimes the cases can be complex and very often, it is a race against time to trace and arrest the suspects. We will need to have a clear mind and be flexible to adapt our strategies and plan accordingly to the evolving and dynamic situations on the ground.At the end of the day, what spurs me on is knowing that what I do can positively impact lives and contribute to a safer Singapore.SPFInFocus singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

caption: Have you seen the Next-generation Fast Response Car (NGFRC) on the streets of Singapore? The SPFs NGFRC is integrated with smart technology to improve our operational effectiveness at the frontline.For instance, the In-Vehicle Video Recording System provides live streaming of high-resolution video footage to the Police Operations Command Centre to allow better sense-making and incident management.The Automated Number Plate Recognition system detects vehicle of interests on the move, without officers having to divert their attention from other ongoing tasks.The SPF will continually strive to explore and adopt technology to improve our frontline capabilities.singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday
cleaned_caption: Have you seen the Next-generation Fast Response Car (NGFRC) on the streets of Singapore? The SPF's NGFRC is integrated with smart technology to improve our operational effectiveness at the frontline. For instance, the In-Vehicle Video Recording System provides live streaming of high-resolution video footage to the Police Operations Command Centre to allow better sense-making and incident management. The Automated Number Plate Recognition system detects vehicles of interest on the move, without officers having to divert their attention from other ongoing tasks. The SPF will continually strive to explore and adopt technology to improve our frontline capabilities.

caption: : Im SSSgt Mohamad Faizal from the Police Security Command, and Im a Personal Security Officer (PSO). As PSOs, our key task is to ensure the safety and security of our VIPs and visiting foreign dignitaries. We undergo rigorous training in close protection tactics, tactical firearms application and advanced vehicle manoeuvring tactics, amongst other skill sets. This enables us to respond swiftly and effectively to any incident when required. As our VIPs frequently meet members of the public and attend events, a challenge that we face is learning how to strike a balance between carrying out our duties and being mindful not to impede our VIPs daily activities. This is a valuable skill that all PSOs gain with experience. The ground situation is dynamic, and being a PSO means that we will always have to be vigilant and alert. This is why you probably always find us looking fierce and not smiling. We have a job to do, and we hope you understand! This job comes with a strong sense of duty and fulfilment, and that is exactly why I chose to be a PSO. SPFinFocus singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

We undergo rigorous training in close protection tactics, tactical firearms application and advanced vehicle manoeuvring tactics, amongst other skill sets. This enables us to respond swiftly and effectively to any incident when required. As our VIPs frequently meet members of the public and attend events, a challenge that we face is learning how to strike a balance between carrying out our duties and being mindful not to impede our VIPs' daily activities. This is a valuable skill that all PSOs gain with experience. The ground situation is dynamic, and being a PSO means that we will always have to be vigilant and alert. This is why you probably always find us looking fierce and not smiling. We have a job to do, and we hope you understand! This job comes with a strong sense of duty and fulfilment, and that is exactly why I chose to be a PSO. SPFinFocus singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

caption: [Joint Exercise @ Raffles Lighthouse]Yesterday, , (MPA), and Police Coast Guard (PCG), conducted a joint exercise at Raffles Lighthouse located at Pulau Satumu. Codenamed Exercise Bluewhale, the exercise simulated responding to contingency scenarios which included a fire at the lighthouse, as well as the rescue of three persons who fell overboard from a ferry. As part of the exercise, a rescue jet ski and a remote-control flotation device were deployed by SCDFs Marine Firefighting Specialists to locate and rescue the casualties. Marine vessels from MPA and PCG were also deployed for cordoning and search operations. Such joint exercises serve to validate and update the respective agencies' joint operational plans and procedures, and also tests the agencies' coordination and response to a major maritime incident. MPA's tour operator, Lionheartlanders, and ferry operator, Marina South Ferries, were also involved in the exercise to practice their emergency procedures should an incident happen during one of the Raffles Lighthouse tours.Check out the photos of the exercise to see our responders in action!

caption: Traffic Police officers keep our roads safe by educating and engaging road users on road safety behaviours, and enforcing traffic laws through their daily patrols and operations assisted by the traffic enforcement cameras.Road users play an important role in keeping our roads safe too!Be gracious, vigilant and responsible on the road so that everyone can have a safe and pleasant journey.Remember, road safety is a shared responsibility! caption: [- ] The Traffic Police, together with the Singapore Road Safety Council (SRSC), held the Anti-Drink Drive Campaign 2023 on 29 November.As part of the campaign, the Guest-Of-Honour MOS Faishal unveiled the campaign tagline, Make the Right Choice: Dont Drink and Drive, to remind motorists to prioritise safety by refraining from driving after consuming alcohol. Remember, drink-driving is an irresponsible act and as we approach the festive season, we would like to remind all motorists to Make the Right Choice to keep our roads safe for everyone. singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday
cleaned_caption: The Traffic Police, together with the Singapore Road Safety Council (SRSC), held the Anti-Drink Drive Campaign 2023 on 29 November. As part of the campaign, the Guest-Of-Honour unveiled the campaign tagline, Make the Right Choice: Don't Drink and Drive, to remind motorists to prioritise safety by refraining from driving after consuming alcohol. Remember, drink-driving is an irresponsible act and as we approach the festive season, we would like to remind all motorists to Make the Right Choice to keep our roads safe for everyone.

caption: Yesterday morning, a counter-terrorism and emergency preparedness exercise, Exercise Heartbeat, was held in the vicinity of Millenia Singapore.This exercise simulates a multi-vector terror attack at the heart of the Marina Downtown to validate the responses by Home Team officers and our community stakeholders during an emergency.The community response - how we stay alert, stay united and stay strong - is crucial in safeguarding Singapore and our way of life.Photos by: SC2 Ryan Quek and SC Zayedsingaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

caption: [ ()]The TBHFS is the first of its kind in Singapore in enabling highly realistic vessel simulation at speeds exceeding 50 knots. It is integrated with an advanced eye-tracking system in addition to weapon capabilities.This simulator can replicate real-world vessel behavior including wave movements and responses, which allows our Police Coast Guard officers to practise their boat handling skills and tactics for various maritime scenarios in a safe environment . Photos by: Naveen Rajsingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

caption: [ ]Dive into the world of our Police Coast Guard (PCG), the SPF unit that safeguards our waters and coastlines! caption: ' : ()Launched in 2015, the POCC is the 24/7 nerve centre of the Singapore Police Force's operations. Comprising of the emergency communications group, the incident watch group and the sense making group, the POCC monitors events big and small, including taking 999 calls, and coordinates the police response to them.When an incident is reported, the POCC proactively seeks out for more information from various sources such as calls from members of public, Police cameras and social media platforms for coordinated sense-making. This information will be provided swiftly to frontline responders to aid in incident management. Additionally, the POCC coordinates island-wide responses to all incidents across Singapore, including activating additional/specialised forces to support frontline officers in managing incidents.Photos by: Naveen Rajsingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

When an incident is reported, the POCC proactively seeks out more information from various sources such as calls from members of the public, Police cameras and social media platforms for coordinated sense-making. This information will be provided swiftly to frontline responders to aid in incident management. Additionally, the POCC coordinates island-wide responses to all incidents across Singapore, including activating additional/specialised forces to support frontline officers in managing incidents.

caption: This seems like it's our personality's perfect match! What did you get?

[ ]Malicious drones pose a threat to our public safety and security as they can be flown into protected areas and can potentially bypass traditional security measures set up to protect a major security event.To counter this threat, the SPF and HTX (Home Team Science and Technology Agency) have developed and deployed counter drone systems that can detect and neutralise rogue drones.The handheld drone jamming system disrupts a drones control signal, stops its flight and allows the Police to retrieve the drone for investigations subsequently.The drone detection system suite consists of both detection sensors and cameras that allow the Police to detect and track the flight path of drones from afar. This allows the Police to take pre-emptive measures to locate the pilot to stop the flight before it poses a danger.The Police will continue to leverage technology to enhance our response against potential and changing threats. Photos by: Naveen Rajsingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeverydayhtxsg
cleaned_caption: Malicious drones pose a threat to our public safety and security as they can be flown into protected areas and can potentially bypass traditional security measures set up to protect a major security event. To counter this threat, the SPF and HTX (Home Team Science and Technology Agency) have developed and deployed counter drone systems that can detect and neutralise rogue drones. The handheld drone jamming system disrupts a drone's control signal, stops its flight and allows the Police to retrieve the drone for investigations subsequently. The drone detection system suite consists of both detection sensors and cameras that allow the Police to detect and track the flight path of drones from afar. This allows the Police to take pre-emptive measures to locate the pilot to stop the flight before it poses a danger. The Police will continue to leverage technology to enhance our response against potential and changing threats.

caption: The Forensics Division of the Criminal Investigation Department is the authority on crime scene forensic matters in the SPF. Forensic Specialists leverage technology to analyse and process evidence gathered at the crime scenes efficiently and accurately to provide investigative leads. For example, fingerprints lifted at scene are screened through the Automated Fingerprint Identification Systems to identify possible suspects. Forensic specialists are also equipped with presumptive blood screening kits to perform rapid, on-site preliminary tests to differentiate between potential blood traces and other stains that resemble blood. Learn how they bring the truth to light in this weeks SPF Glossary! singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

caption: ! - - On 23rd April 2023, Senior Staff Sergeant Shaari was off-duty when he saw a man holding what seemed to be a sharp, curved object. He looked like he was in a daze. I sensed that the situation could potentially become dangerous. I asked my family to stay inside the car. My mother grew worried and tried to stop me from approaching the man. But if I let this pass, who knows what could happen next? ourpolicestories singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

caption: From the grandstand to the bright lights of the track, the Singapore Police and an INTERPOL Major Event Support Team worked together to ensure a safe and secure F1 weekend for all! Officers facilitated real-time exchange of messages and information among countries, including on stolen and lost travel documents.The SPF and INTERPOL have proudly been working hand in hand to secure the F1 SingaporeGP night race annually since 2016. The worlds largest policing organization is officially marking its 100-year anniversary, celebrating a century of international police cooperation. Heres to many more years of police cooperation ahead!Photos by: Naveen Raj and INTERPOLF1 SingaporeGPsingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeverydayInterpol100PoliceCooperation
cleaned_caption: From the grandstand to the bright lights of the track, the Singapore Police and an INTERPOL Major Event Support Team worked together to ensure a safe and secure F1 weekend for all! Officers facilitated real-time exchange of messages and information among countries, including on stolen and lost travel documents. The SPF and INTERPOL have proudly been working hand in hand to secure the F1 SingaporeGP night race annually since 2016. The world's largest policing organization is officially marking its 100-year anniversary, celebrating a century of international police cooperation. Here's to many more years of police cooperation ahead!

caption: Our Crime Scene Specialists identify relevant forensic evidence at crime scenes and conduct thorough investigations to ensure that truth is brought to light Evidence at the scene is properly highlighted, marked and labelled. Blood sampling kits may be used for DNA identification and fingerprints are photographed, lifted and preserved for possible matches in the labs. All exhibits are eventually packed and secured in appropriate packaging materials to serve legal and scientific requirements and most importantly to prevent loss, alteration, damage and contamination.Which unit should we capture next? Best three comments get pinned Photos by: Naveen Raj singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

caption: , How would you feel if the victim that had fallen to a scam was a loved one? says ASP Irina Ng, a senior investigation officer from the Anti-Scam Command (ASC) of the Commercial Affairs Department who feels the need to raise more awareness for scams.The ASC functions as a nerve centre in the fight against scams, and ASC officers including Irina work closely with partners such as the banks, FinTech companies and other government agencies to promptly follow up on cases to prevent monetary losses by victims. The challenge is to stay one step ahead. Scams ARE preventable. Stay vigilant, think before you act and question before committing any transfers.ourpolicestories singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

The ASC functions as a nerve centre in the fight against scams, and ASC officers work closely with partners such as the banks, FinTech companies and other government agencies to promptly follow up on cases to prevent monetary losses by victims. The challenge is to stay one step ahead. Scams ARE preventable. Stay vigilant, think before you act and question before committing any transfers. #ourpolicestories #sgpoliceforce #safeguardingeveryday

caption: This year, The Singapore Police Force Scholarship and Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) Scholarships Award Ceremony was held at The Istana on 18 August, with Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Law, Mr K Shanmugam as the Guest of Honour. Inspector Edison Chua and Inspector Chen Hong Wen received The Singapore Police Force Scholarship, one of the most prestigious awards, alongside 32 other Ministry of Home Affairs Scholars that evening. Upon completion of their studies, they will undergo structured residential training at the Police Training Command that includes police defence tactics, criminal investigation, physical training, as well as leadership development. Subsequently, they will be posted to the Police Divisions to assume operational and command appointments, as part of their development to be future leaders of the Force. Congratulations to all scholarship recipients!Find out more on

caption: The Police K-9 Unit plays an important role in keeping Singapore safe and secure.The K-9 dogs and their handlers are often deployed to support other police units in frontline operations. One such pair is SSS Chia Wei and Rocky! Rocky is an Explosive Detection Dog from Australia, and he has been Chia Wei's 'partner' for the last 7 years!Rocky is trained to identify a wide range of explosive substances and is deployed with Chia Wei at various locations such as the checkpoints and airport to prevent and detect crime! Photos by: SC Ryan Queksingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

caption: Heartiest congratulations to The Singapore Police Force Scholarship holder Inspector Chua Jia Zhi, Edison on being awarded the prestigious Presidents Scholarship during the Presidents Scholarship Award Ceremony held at the Istana on 15 August 2023.His outstanding academic performance, leadership qualities, and dedication to serving in the Police Force are truly inspiring. He will be pursuing an Economics Degree at the University of California, Los Angeles in the United States of America.

caption: The Crisis Negotiation Unit (CNU) of the Singapore Police Force responds to hostage situations, barricade incidents and attempted suicides.With their specialised training and negotiation skills, CNU officers can help save lives and bring about positive outcomes in challenging situations.Photos by: Naveen Rajsingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

caption: Police psychological services have existed within the Singapore Police Force since 1993 and the Police Psychological Services Department was established in April 2021.Police psychologists, such as Bryan Danni, are involved in areas of work relating to assessment psychology, leadership psychology, operations psychology, crime psychology and resilience psychology. For example, Bryan is involved in providing psychological training and counselling for police officers. He also offers operational assistance during crisis negotiation scenarios.Photos by: Naveen Rajsingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

caption: - Contact Tactics sessions are designed to simulate real-life scenarios to develop officers decision-making skills and tactical awareness. Most importantly, officers are trained to only apply the appropriate levels of force necessary to prevent subjects from harming themselves or others. caption: , ! The Police Guard of Honour (GOH) contingent in this year's National Day Parade (NDP) will be led by DSP Benson Chong. caption: : Officers from our Police Logistics Department (PLD) play an important role in supporting, equipping and sustaining the SPFs operations at the frontline. They help put in place security infrastructures and provide officers with the necessary resources so that they can carry out their duties effectively.For this years National Day Parade, PLDofficers havestartedpreparing for the logistical requirements as early as December 2022. They coordinated with vendors and various SPF units on the deployment of the safety barricades, oversaw the setting up of walk-through metal detectors at person check stations and put up command posts and rest areas for SPF officers amongst other logistical operations.PLD officers continue to work tirelessly on the groundeven afteranevent has ended toremove the structures and barricades quickly so that normalcy can resume as soon as possible after the security operations have concluded.Kudos to our PLD logisticians who are always the first in and last out, providing timely mission-centric capabilities in supporting SPFs major operations!Photos by: Naveen Rajsingaporepoliceforce OnwardAsOneSGNDP2023HappyBirthdaySingapore
cleaned_caption: Officers from our Police Logistics Department (PLD) play an important role in supporting, equipping and sustaining the SPF's operations at the frontline. They help put in place security infrastructures and provide officers with the necessary resources so that they can carry out their duties effectively. For this year's National Day Parade, PLD officers have started preparing for the logistical requirements as early as December 2022. They coordinated with vendors and various SPF units on the deployment of the safety barricades, oversaw the setting up of walk-through metal detectors at person check stations and put up command posts and rest areas for SPF officers among other logistical operations. PLD officers continue to work tirelessly on the ground even after an event has ended to remove the structures and barricades quickly so that normalcy can resume as soon as possible after the security operations have concluded. Kudos to our PLD logisticians who are always the first in and last out, providing timely mission-centric capabilities in supporting SPF's major operations!

caption: () On 27 May afternoon, police volunteer Wayne Koo was having lunch with his friend near Whampoa.We were about to leave when we suddenly heard a loud explosion coming from the road. We saw the front engine of a recycling truck had caught fire. Instead of running away, he bravely ran towards the fire, putting out the fire together with onlookers. No one was harmed, and no other properties were damaged. DAC (V) Koo was awarded the Community First Responder Award by the SCDF in June, 2023 for his brave acts.As a VSC (Volunteer Special Constabulary)officer, sometimes you ask yourself whether you are in this for the job or for the mission. The scheme may be voluntary, but the role and mission are not. You are vested with the responsibility. We come from all walks of life. But once you put on that blue uniform, all of us are equal. Its meaningful and I want to step forward to inspire others. ourpolicestories singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

As a Volunteer Special Constabulary officer, sometimes you ask yourself whether you are in this for the job or for the mission. The scheme may be voluntary, but the role and mission are not. You are vested with the responsibility. We come from all walks of life. But once you put on that blue uniform, all of us are equal. It's meaningful and I want to step forward to inspire others. #ourpolicestories #singaporepoliceforce #safeguardingeveryday

caption: This morning, four officers from the Singapore Police Force (SPF) took part in the Community Chest Vertical Marathon - a 57-storey climb, at the Marina Bay Sands. This event, co-organised by Community Chest and Marina Bay Sands, aims to rally the community to build a caring and inclusive society for all.The SPF team comprising Eng Kiong, Junqiang, Subas and Bigyan, emerged champion with a combined timing of 28min 17s. The SPF is proud to be part of this meaningful event that brings together people from all walks of life to raise funds for the less fortunate in Singapore.For more than 30 years, the SPF had been supporting the Community Chest to care for the disadvantaged in our community.singaporepoliceforce

The SPF is proud to be part of this meaningful event that brings together people from all walks of life to raise funds for the less fortunate in Singapore. For more than 30 years, the SPF had been supporting the Community Chest to care for the disadvantaged in our community.

caption: Constructed in 2006, the Boarding and Search Trainer (BST) is purpose-built and designed to resemble a merchant cargo vessel. The BST provides a realistic training environment for Police Coast Guard (PCG) officers to train their operational tactics. The BST has a 25 meters indoor firing range that is specially designed for various tactical firearms training. Thunder flashes and stun grenades can be deployed in the range to support complex training requirements. It also comes installed with a Range Management System allowing officers to remotely manage the electronic target system and simulate various lighting conditions and sound environments. The newly installed Rope Access Platform consists of fast roping beams and rappelling anchor points. This facility allows multiple personnel to descend simultaneously, providing a rapid and efficient means of insertion into a hostile vessel. This new platform will enable officers to train and practise quick and safe descent from elevated positions to a cushioned lower platform. There are also Close-Quarters Battle Areas within the BST that can accommodate both live firing and non-live firing trainings. The non-live firing area consists of single to multiple rooms setting, and the rooms are built with hidden compartments and false ceilings to train officers in vessel rummaging. The live-firing area in each deck is made up of a modular layout that allows the setup for the deck to be changed for each training session, helping to increase the realism of the training as the participants cannot predict the decks layout. The BST enhances the training of PCG officers to ensure they are operationally ready to safeguard Singapores territorial waters every day. singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

caption: The Tactical Strike Vehicle (TSV) is part of the fleet of vehicles under the Special Operations Command (SOC) to augment its tactical capabilities and protection. These vehicles are heavily fortified with protective wire mesh and armored bodies, ensuring they are well shielded to effectively counter and neutralize potential threats. Equipped with features such as a public announcement system, blinkers and floodlights, the TSVs project a strong police presence, acting as a deterrent to perpetrators. The TSVs are also equipped with an array of powerful cameras to facilitate sensemaking and threat detection.singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

caption: [ !]The Police Community Roadshow (PCR) has made a comeback after a five-year hiatus!This years PCR features the latest technologies and equipment used by the SPF to keep our community safe and secure, which include the Unmanned Aerial Vehicles, the Next Generation Fast Response Car and various weaponry.There will also be live demonstrations of the SPFs capabilities, and performances by the SPF band and the Police K-9 unit. In addition, visitors can experience hands-on crime scene investigations in a mock-up scene.So what are you waiting for? Join us at the PCR at One Punggol today!policecommunityroadshow2023 singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday
cleaned_caption: The Police Community Roadshow (PCR) has made a comeback after a five-year hiatus! caption: - On 10 May 2023 at about 12pm, Yi Jun and Chong Wei were out for brunch with their family at a coffeeshop in Woodlands when they encountered an incident with a man wielding a chopper.The brother-sister duo recount how they quickly worked together to disarm him before calling for the Police to arrest the man.When asked about how they acted in this incident, Yi Jun mentioned that as police officers we are trained to look out for security threats and to stop them immediately if we are able to do so. We feel this way even when were off-duty! Chong Wei also mentioned that he was happy that they were able to resolve the incident quickly with no harm done to anyone. I just wanted to play a bigger role in helping keep Singapore and my community safe, which is why I chose to join the SPF.ourpolicestories singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday
cleaned_caption: On 10 May 2023 at about 12pm, two individuals were out for brunch with their family at a coffeeshop in Woodlands when they encountered an incident with a man wielding a chopper. The duo recounted how they quickly worked together to disarm him before calling for the Police to arrest the man. When asked about how they acted in this incident, one mentioned that as police officers, they are trained to look out for security threats and to stop them immediately if they are able to do so. They feel this way even when off-duty! The other also mentioned that they were happy to have resolved the incident quickly with no harm done to anyone, noting a desire to play a bigger role in helping keep Singapore and the community safe, which is why they chose to join the Singapore Police Force.

We feel this way even when were off-duty! Chong Wei also mentioned that he was happy that they were able to resolve the incident quickly with no harm done to anyone. They quickly worked together to disarm him before calling for the Police to arrest the man. When asked about how they acted in this incident, one mentioned that as police officers they are trained to look out for security threats and to stop them immediately if they are able to do so. They feel this way even when off-duty! The other also mentioned that they were happy to resolve the incident quickly with no harm done to anyone, expressing a desire to play a bigger role in helping keep Singapore and the community safe, which is why they chose to join the Singapore Police Force.

caption: () , Inspired by the Hong Kong TV police dramas in the 1990s, AC Serene Chiu joined the Singapore Police Force in 1999. She has since stayed on for over 23 years.For officers who have worked with her, you would have known her as someone who is jovial, yet focused, driven and firm during operations and missions. AC Serene Chiu now leads Clementi Police Division, which was recently named the Best Land Division at the Police Day Parade on 3 June 2023. Today, we speak to her to find out what are the secrets in winning the award.Theres no secret in winning (laughs)! But I do like to credit my officers for maintaining a high standard of operational excellence and professionalism. They will chase down every lead to solve every crime they can and ensure justice is served. The Division is outstanding because of its people who give their utmost to keep Singapore safe and secure every day.And of course, I would also like to thank our community partners and stakeholders, who have actively contributed to creating safer communities. Technology plays an important role too. We use data-driven approach to identify crime patterns to better plan our deterrence patrols and crime prevention efforts, and Police cameras have been effective in helping us deter and solve crimes.[To be continued]

caption: - The Singapore Police Force (SPF) held the Police Day Parade 2023 on 3 June 2023 at the Home Team Academy. Mr Lawrence Wong, Deputy Prime Minister (DPM) and Minister for Finance, was the Guest-of-Honour at the parade which saw 650 participants from the various Police divisions, specialist units, Volunteer Special Constabulary, and cadets from the National Police Cadet Corps.Commemorated annually on 3 June since 1971, Police Day celebrates the SPFs achievements, recognises the contributions of past and present officers, and brings officers together to renew our pledge to serve Singapore and to carry out our duties with courage, loyalty, integrity, and fairness.Here are some photos taken at the Parade yesterday!policeday2023

Mr Lawrence Wong, Deputy Prime Minister (DPM) and Minister for Finance, was the Guest-of-Honour at the parade which saw 650 participants from the various Police divisions, specialist units, Volunteer Special Constabulary, and cadets from the National Police Cadet Corps.Commemorated annually on 3 June since 1971, Police Day celebrates the SPFs achievements, recognises the contributions of past and present officers, and brings officers together to renew our pledge to serve Singapore and to carry out our duties with courage, loyalty, integrity, and fairness.Here are some photos taken at the Parade yesterday!policeday2023
cleaned_caption: The Singapore Police Force (SPF) held the Police Day Parade 2023 on 3 June 2023 at the Home Team Academy. The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance was the Guest-of-Honour at the parade which saw 650 participants from the various Police divisions, specialist units, Volunteer Special Constabulary, and cadets from the National Police Cadet Corps. Commemorated annually on 3 June since 1971, Police Day celebrates the SPF's achievements, recognises the contributions of past and present officers, and brings officers together to renew our pledge to serve Singapore and to carry out our duties with courage, loyalty, integrity, and fairness. Here are some photos taken at the Parade yesterday! #policeday2023

caption: - () , You would have known Insp Majid if you were a police trainee who had graduated from the Police Training Command over the past decade.Majid is a Field Instructor and as the Parade Conducting Officer for Police Day Parade 2023, he is responsible for conducting drill training and rehearsals for officers participating in the Parade. As a trainer, I emphasise a high standard of drill for parades and ceremonies from the officers. It is an honour to be the Parade Conducting Officer and I'm confident that the officers would do the SPF proud in this years Police Day Parade.Join us at the Police Day Parade 2023 as we bring the Parade LIVE to you on SPF's Facebook page from 5:45pm tomorrow! PS: How many of you have seen, heard or trained by him during your training? Share your experience with us! Photos by: Naveen Rajpoliceday2023

caption: : On 20 March 2022, after drinks with his friends at a restaurant along Merchant Road, 29-year-old Justin Chua left the group for a while to head to a nearby convenience store at about 10.45pm. In a flash and without any warning, he was struck on the back of his head multiple times with a glass bottle and assaulted by a group of men.With the assistance of the Police cameras and the use of Video Analytics, the Police managed to track down those responsible for the attack and arrested all of them within two weeks of the reported crime.crimefiles singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

caption: : At the recently concluded SEA Games 2023, SC/Cpl Nufail Raiyan from the Protective Security Command (ProCom) and SGT Felissa Lai from Woodlands Division clinched the silver and bronze medals respectively in the mens and womens field hockey team event.When speaking to Felissa, she mentioned that as a Ground Response Force officer, good teamwork and clear communications are key to success in any operations. Likewise, in team sports like field hockey, it is important that everyone of us work together as a team and communicate effective on the pitch so that we can execute our game plan effectively. She added that she is thankful to her Team Leader and her teammates for their support, so that she could concentrate on achieving the best results at the Games.Raiyan added that his training at ProCom taught him to be resilient and always give his best in whatever he does. His efforts will pay off at the end of the day. He adopted this mentality in every match during the SEA Games. Raiyan said, I am thankful to my family and friends as well as my teammates and colleagues in ProCom for their encouragement. I wouldnt have done it without them!Congratulations to Felissa and Raiyan for their wins!Pic 1: Felissa (left) with her teammatePic 2: Photo of SGT FelissaPic 3: Raiyan at the Sea Games 2023 Pic 4: Photo of SC/Cpl Raiyan
cleaned_caption: At the recently concluded SEA Games 2023, SC/Cpl from the Protective Security Command (ProCom) and SGT from Woodlands Division clinched the silver and bronze medals respectively in the mens and womens field hockey team event. When speaking to SGT, she mentioned that as a Ground Response Force officer, good teamwork and clear communications are key to success in any operations. Likewise, in team sports like field hockey, it is important that everyone works together as a team and communicates effectively on the pitch so that they can execute their game plan effectively. She added that she is thankful to her Team Leader and her teammates for their support, so that she could concentrate on achieving the best results at the Games. SC/Cpl added that his training at ProCom taught him to be resilient and always give his best in whatever he does. His efforts will pay off at the end of the day. He adopted this mentality in every match during the SEA Games. SC/Cpl said, he is thankful to his family and friends as well as his teammates and colleagues in ProCom for their encouragement. Congratulations to SGT and SC/Cpl for their wins!

caption: - : Man Kumar (K): In the late morning of 25 Mar 2023, my team and I were driving in the vicinity of Woodlands Industrial Park. Sabin (S): While driving, I spotted what appeared to be a cyclist lying on the road. He looked to be unconscious. We all sensed that there was something amiss. Dinesh Limbu (D): We quickly stopped our vehicle and dashed over to him. Jeevan Gharti (J): The cyclist was unresponsive to our calls. When Dinesh and I checked for his pulse, we found out that there was no breathing. K: We realised that this was a matter of life and death. I instructed Dinesh and Jeevan to quickly perform CPR on him. D: Although all of us are trained in CPR, it was my first time doing it in a real life scenario. All I could think about was how to save this persons life. K: As I was giving a call to the ambulance, Sabin ensured safety by blocking the road lane and directing traffic. S: We also helped to move the cyclist to a shaded grass patch nearby and continued to perform CPR. J: The ambulance soon arrived and he was conveyed to the hospital. We later learned that the cyclist had survived and was eventually discharged. K: I feel very proud of my team. We handled a critical situation effectively. D: Protecting lives and properties are always key objectives in our missions. K: We are just happy that we are able to save a precious life. I hope he is recovering well! singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday
cleaned_caption: In the late morning of 25 Mar 2023, my team and I were driving in the vicinity of Woodlands Industrial Park. While driving, I spotted what appeared to be a cyclist lying on the road. He looked to be unconscious. We all sensed that there was something amiss. We quickly stopped our vehicle and dashed over to him. The cyclist was unresponsive to our calls. When we checked for his pulse, we found out that there was no breathing. We realised that this was a matter of life and death. I instructed my team to quickly perform CPR on him. Although all of us are trained in CPR, it was my first time doing it in a real life scenario. All I could think about was how to save this person's life. As I was giving a call to the ambulance, my team ensured safety by blocking the road lane and directing traffic. We also helped to move the cyclist to a shaded grass patch nearby and continued to perform CPR. The ambulance soon arrived and he was conveyed to the hospital. We later learned that the cyclist had survived and was eventually discharged. I feel very proud of my team. We handled a critical situation effectively. Protecting lives and properties are always key objectives in our missions. We are just happy that we are able to save a precious life. I hope he is recovering well! #sgpoliceforce #safeguardingeveryday

When Dinesh and I checked for his pulse, we found out that there was no breathing. K: We realised that this was a matter of life and death. I instructed Dinesh and Jeevan to quickly perform CPR on him. D: Although all of us are trained in CPR, it was my first time doing it in a real life scenario. All I could think about was how to save this persons life. K: As I was giving a call to the ambulance, Sabin ensured safety by blocking the road lane and directing traffic. S: We also helped to move the cyclist to a shaded grass patch nearby and continued to perform CPR. J: The ambulance soon arrived and he was conveyed to the hospital. We later learned that the cyclist had survived and was eventually discharged. K: I feel very proud of my team. We handled a critical situation effectively. D: Protecting lives and properties are always key objectives in our missions. K: We are just happy that we are able to save a precious life. I hope he is recovering well! singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

caption: Scam alert! Check out the following infographics on how scammers have used a fake ScamShield App for their latest phishing scam. Do not download any files from third-party or dubious sites to your device. This may lead to phishing malware being installed unknowingly, which allows scammers to take control of your device to steal personal/banking information for unauthorised transactions! If you have any information relating to such crimes or when in doubt, please call the Police Hotline at 1800-255-0000, or submit information online at For more information on scams, members of the public can visit or call the Anti-Scam Helpline at 1800-722-6688.

caption: / !At the ongoing SEA Games 2023, SC/SGT Ethan Poh from Public Transport Security Command (TransCom) and his team mates clinched the men's table tennis (team) gold medal for Singapore! Ethan grabbed another bronze medal earlier today at the Men's Double competition. When speaking to Ethan, Discipline and determination are two key values that I picked up through police trainings at the Home Team Academy.Small things like doing stretching daily and eating healthily may seem mundane, but they go a long way in helping me excel in sports. Being disciplined and having great determination to succeed helped me pull through.Ethan added that he would not have been able to focus on his competition without the full support from his family and his team at TransCom. His achievements would not have been possible without their support.Congratulations to Ethan and the men's table tennis team, and all the best to our Team Singapore athletes competing in the remaining competitions at SEA Games 2023!

caption: My two-and-a-half years old twin girls were either asleep when I got home, or when I left for work, recalled DAC Tay of the early days of her Checkpoints posting, when her team had to conduct multiple exercises at the checkpoints during odd hours, in order to avoid the morning and evening peak periods.That was when my mum guilt would kick in, she shared, but at the end of the day, everything worked out because of the strong support I received from my family, supervisors and team. Now that her twins are 12 years old, DAC Tay says with a chuckle that shes become their excuse to stay up past bedtime, as they eagerly wait for me to come home after my work! Happy Mothers Day to all the mothers out there!

caption: The Police have arrested a 52-year-old man for his suspected involvement in a case of outrage of modesty.On 11 April 2023 at about 9.50pm, the Police were alerted to an incident where a woman was purportedly molested by a man in the vicinity of Changi Road.Through ground enquiries, coordination with the Police Operations Command Centre, and with the aid of Police cameras and the use of video analytics, officers from Bedok Police Division located the 52-year-old man and arrested him along Haig Road at 12.20am on 12 April 2023, within three hours of the reported crime.The man will be charged on 13 April 2023 with outrage of modesty under Section 354(1) of the Penal Code 1871. The offence carries an imprisonment term which may extend to three years, or a fine, or caning, or any combination of such punishments.

caption: [ ]On 10 April 2023 at 4.56pm, the Police were informed that a man was lost in the forested area within the MacRitchie Nature Trail & Reservoir Park.Police resources including officers from Tanglin Division, Gurkha Contingent and the Aerial Response Team were swiftly deployed to locate the missing man. Officers from and also assisted in the search.The missing man was subsequently located at 7.02pm. He was found together with a fellow male hiker. Both men, aged 67 and 51, were unhurt.NParks would also like to advise the public to stay on the designated trails while trekking, and observe the opening hours of our nature reserves and nature parks, which are 7am to 7pm. For urgent matters, they can call the NParks helpline at 1800-471 7300.

caption: [ ]On 22 Mar 2023, the Singapore Police Force participated in Exercise Northstar XI.Held at Jurong Island, this exercise tests out the drills and coordination among various government agencies and community stakeholders should a terror attack happen in Singapore. Police officers responded to various scenarios involving IEDs, hostage situations, high-speed boat chase and mass evacuation in this exercise. Check out the highlights from Exercise Northstar XI! singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday spfcapabilities onehometeam

caption: Our Police Stories - International Womens Day special Since their entry into the Force in 1949, female police officers have been constantly pushing their boundaries to achieve greater heights in an otherwise male-dominated profession. Meet INSP Stephanie Lim, one of the female officers currently serving in the SPF. Let us take a moment on International Womens Day today, to embraceequity and recognise the contributions of all policewomen in the Force. OurPoliceStories singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday embraceequity

caption: In addition to static traffic enforcement cameras deployed across Singapore, the Traffic Police deploys portable speed laser cameras to deter and detect speeding.Manned by a single officer, this portable speed laser camera is compact and easy to deploy. It is capable of capturing high-resolution images and works well even in low-light conditions. The violations captured from these cameras will then be processed accordingly.The portable speed laser cameras are but one tool available to the Traffic Police. While we will continue our three-pronged approach to maintain safer roads through education, engagement, and enforcement, we need all road users to continue practising good road safety habits and play their part in keeping Singapores roads safe. Remember, road safety is a shared responsibility.singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday
cleaned_caption: In addition to static traffic enforcement cameras deployed across Singapore, the Traffic Police deploys portable speed laser cameras to deter and detect speeding. Manned by a single officer, this portable speed laser camera is compact and easy to deploy. It is capable of capturing high-resolution images and works well even in low-light conditions. The violations captured from these cameras will then be processed accordingly. The portable speed laser cameras are but one tool available to the Traffic Police. While we will continue our three-pronged approach to maintain safer roads through education, engagement, and enforcement, we need all road users to continue practising good road safety habits and play their part in keeping Singapore's roads safe. Remember, road safety is a shared responsibility.

caption: - Looking forward to catching Blackpink, Harry Styles or buying tickets to other big concerts this year? Read this before you become first in line for a concert ticket scam! In 2022, over 199 police reports were made in relation to scams involving concert tickets with victims suffering losses of at least $175,000! This was more than 48 times the amount lost for the same period in 2021! So heres some advice if youre looking to buy from third-party resellers: Physically meet with the seller to verify the tickets BEFORE making payment, no matter how eager you are Choose buyer protection within the platform and avoid making advance payments Buy only from authorised sellers or reputable sources Stay safe and enjoy the music! spotthesignssgscamalert
cleaned_caption: - Looking forward to catching Blackpink, Harry Styles or buying tickets to other big concerts this year? Read this before you become first in line for a concert ticket scam! In 2022, over 199 police reports were made in relation to scams involving concert tickets with victims suffering losses of at least $175,000! This was more than 48 times the amount lost for the same period in 2021! So here's some advice if you're looking to buy from third-party resellers: Physically meet with the seller to verify the tickets BEFORE making payment, no matter how eager you are. Choose buyer protection within the platform and avoid making advance payments. Buy only from authorised sellers or reputable sources. Stay safe and enjoy the music!

caption: , : & .Ibnu Musalli (I): I always find that police officers are in a unique position to make a difference to victims and vulnerable persons. There are so many different incidents we attend to. Foot chases can be exciting but sometimes there are other cases which bring a different kind of meaningfulness.Miqdad Fisall (M): Just last month, Ibnu and I received a call for police assistance on 27 November evening stating that a woman had been reported missing.I: Yes, the caller was her relative and was troubled by the fact that she was uncontactable for the past four days. He had even gone to her apartment unit to make checks but had gotten no response from her. Her mobile phone was switched off as well.M: Were familiar with the terrain here at Clementi NPC and quickly headed down to make enquiries at her apartment building.I: We made some quick checks with her neighbours. What the neighbours said were consistent with the relative. They had not seen the missing lady for three or four days. M: We also noticed that there were a few delivery parcels that have been left outside her house.I: However, our instincts and experience told us that she might still be in her unit but in a condition where she couldnt respond.M: As we were speaking to the neighbours, we heard some faint rapping sounds coming from the other side of the wall. This further confirmed our suspicions that she might still be inside.I: We had to act quickly so with the help of the security guard, we managed to gain access to her unit.M: The house was dimly-lit and appeared to be empty. As we walked further in, the faint knocking began to grow louder. I: Yes, the source of knocking seemed to be coming from the bathroom area.M: I cried out Miss, we are the Police! Were here to help you! To our relief, she responded![To be continued in comment section]
cleaned_caption: I always find that police officers are in a unique position to make a difference to victims and vulnerable persons. There are so many different incidents we attend to. Foot chases can be exciting but sometimes there are other cases which bring a different kind of meaningfulness. Just last month, we received a call for police assistance on 27 November evening stating that a woman had been reported missing. The caller was her relative and was troubled by the fact that she was uncontactable for the past four days. He had even gone to her apartment unit to make checks but had gotten no response from her. Her mobile phone was switched off as well. We were familiar with the terrain here at Clementi NPC and quickly headed down to make enquiries at her apartment building. We made some quick checks with her neighbours. What the neighbours said were consistent with the relative. They had not seen the missing lady for three or four days. We also noticed that there were a few delivery parcels that have been left outside her house. However, our instincts and experience told us that she might still be in her unit but in a condition where she couldn't respond. As we were speaking to the neighbours, we heard some faint rapping sounds coming from the other side of the wall. This further confirmed our suspicions that she might still be inside. We had to act quickly so with the help of the security guard, we managed to gain access to her unit. The house was dimly-lit and appeared to be empty. As we walked further in, the faint knocking began to grow louder. Yes, the source of knocking seemed to be coming from the bathroom area. I cried out, "Miss, we are the Police! We're here to help you!" To our relief, she responded! [To be continued in comment section]

caption: - The Police K-9 Unit plays an important role in keeping Singapore safe and secure.The Police Dog Unit (former name of the Police K-9 Unit) was first established in 1955, and the dogs were mainly trained to track suspects and to conduct patrols.Over time, the unit has grown both in size and capabilities. In 2003, it was renamed as the Police K-9 Unit and reorganised to be part of the newly established Special Operations Command.Today, there are more than 230 working dogs in the Police K-9 Unit, and they play key roles in various police operations, ranging from finding explosives, tracking missing persons to providing security coverage for major events.

Today, there are more than 230 working dogs in the Police K-9 Unit, and they play key roles in various police operations, ranging from finding explosives, tracking missing persons to providing security coverage for major events.

caption: - - Post-blast investigation (PBI) is a key operational capability for the SPF, especially with the existing threat of terrorism.The SPF works closely with local and foreign stakeholders to ensure that we remainoperationally ready and competent to deal with bomb-blast incidents."Exercise Solar Wind is an important platform that provides a realistic training environment for officers from the Singapore Police Force and the Royal Brunei Police Force to jointly undergo PBI training. We will continue to work with our strategic partners to enhance our PBI capabilities. " - Deputy Commissioner of Police (Investigation & Intelligence), Mr How Kwang Hweesafeguardingeverydaysingaporepoliceforce

caption: , : , . .My family and I were enjoying our afternoon at home during my day off on 28 Sep 2020. This peacefulness was interrupted when we suddenly heard screams of a woman coming from downstairs. My house on the third floor overlooks the carpark. As I peered out, a shocking sight greeted me a young lady was frantically fleeing from a knife-wielding man!The woman was screaming and clearly in distress. I know this might sound quite dramatic but I quickly dashed out of the house while telling my family members I need to go down, I need to save the girl!.It wasnt wise to confront a man with a knife alone so as I ran past some migrant workers who were working nearby, I asked if they had anything I could use to protect myself. They quickly handed me a hoe from their worksite and I ran towards the couple.Once at the carpark, I saw that a driver had stopped and used his car to block the man from reaching the woman. The man was still waving his knife and shouting incoherently.A crowd had already formed by then. For everyones safety, I knew I had to defuse the situation as soon as possible. I addressed him calmly. Im a police officer. Please drop your knife.Suddenly, he began charging towards me with his knife. Fortunately, I managed to deflect his blow by quickly swinging the hoe at him. He backed away. I saw the mans eyes darting around when he realised that there wasnt anywhere for him to run. The crowd had him surrounded. In a panic, he pointed the knife towards himself and started slashing at his own arms.I took this chance to quickly grab his wrist and disarmed him. Some nearby onlookers then rushed in and together we successfully subdued the man. Soon enough, police officers arrived and arrested him. Both the man and woman were later brought to a hospital to treat their injuries. [To be continued in comment section]

They quickly handed me a hoe from their worksite and I ran towards the couple. Once at the carpark, I saw that a driver had stopped and used his car to block the man from reaching the woman. The man was still waving his knife and shouting incoherently. A crowd had already formed by then. For everyone's safety, I knew I had to defuse the situation as soon as possible. I addressed him calmly. I'm a police officer. Please drop your knife. Suddenly, he began charging towards me with his knife. Fortunately, I managed to deflect his blow by quickly swinging the hoe at him. He backed away. I saw the man's eyes darting around when he realised that there wasn't anywhere for him to run. The crowd had him surrounded. In a panic, he pointed the knife towards himself and started slashing at his own arms. I took this chance to quickly grab his wrist and disarmed him. Some nearby onlookers then rushed in and together we successfully subdued the man. Soon enough, police officers arrived and arrested him. Both the man and woman were later brought to a hospital to treat their injuries. [To be continued in comment section]

caption: Community policing is one of the key thrusts of the Singapore Police Forces policing strategy to actively involve the community in keeping Singapore safe and secure. In the 1970s and 80s, the Police were faced with rising crime cases. To better fight crime, community-based policing strategy was introduced via the Neighbourhood Police Post (NPP) system in 1983. The NPP system focused on leveraging community support in the areas of crime prevention and detection. In 1997, the NPP system evolved into the Neighbourhood Police Centre (NPC) system. The NPCs serve as one-stop policing centres and bring a wider range of police services closer to the community. The Community Policing System (COPS) system was introduced in 2012 to further strengthen our partnership with the community. Under COPS, the Community Policing Unit (CPU) was formed as a full-fledged unit to take on community policing roles. Clad in their signature white polo tees and blue bermudas, CPU officers build closer relationships with the community and stakeholders through physical and online engagements. Over the years, volunteer schemes such as the Community Watch Scheme (CWS), Citizens on Patrol (COP), Volunteer Special Constabulary (VSC) and VSC (Community) have also been introduced to empower the community to be our Enabled Police Partners. These volunteers play an important role in keeping Singapore safe and secure. Interested in partnering with us? Join us as a volunteer (link in bio).

caption: , : , . .SI Fadzly (F): There are many tourist spots and commercial areas within the jurisdiction of Marina Bay NPC so we see a lot of different types of cases.SGT Junjie (JJ): On 16 July this year, we received a report that a girl had gone missing from her hotel room.ASP Benjamin (B): We moved quickly and met up with the girls parents at their hotel lobby.JJ: Being tourists, they were understandably distraught and worried as their daughter had gone missing in a foreign country. They also shared with us that she was suffering from anxiety and mental health issues.B: Learning this, our priority was to find the missing girl to prevent her from any possible harms. I apprised my officers quickly and all of us sprung into action.F: We needed to quickly come up with a plan. Which likely direction would their daughter have headed off to? How do we best deploy our officers?B: Im thankful that my team has a high level of competency. Everyone stepped up to the plate to do what they needed to do.F: While some of my colleagues went to the command centre to check the CCTVs, the others relayed the descriptions of the missing girl to the Police Operations Command Centre so that they can disseminate the information to all frontline police officers.JJ: Concurrently, we checked with the parents and learned that their daughter had a location-sharing app activated on her phone. Fadzly and I tracked to her last-known location within the hotel premises where we eventually found her.[To be continued in comment section]

They also shared with us that she was suffering from anxiety and mental health issues. B: Learning this, our priority was to find the missing girl to prevent her from any possible harms. I apprised my officers quickly and all of us sprung into action. F: We needed to quickly come up with a plan. Which likely direction would their daughter have headed off to? cleaned_caption: , : , . . There are many tourist spots and commercial areas within the jurisdiction of Marina Bay NPC so we see a lot of different types of cases. On 16 July this year, we received a report that a girl had gone missing from her hotel room. We moved quickly and met up with the girl's parents at their hotel lobby. Being tourists, they were understandably distraught and worried as their daughter had gone missing in a foreign country. They also shared with us that she was suffering from anxiety and mental health issues. Learning this, our priority was to find the missing girl to prevent her from any possible harms. I apprised my officers quickly and all of us sprung into action. We needed to quickly come up with a plan. Which likely direction would their daughter have headed off to? How do we best deploy our officers? I’m thankful that my team has a high level of competency. Everyone stepped up to the plate to do what they needed to do. While some of my colleagues went to the command centre to check the CCTVs, the others relayed the descriptions of the missing girl to the Police Operations Command Centre so that they can disseminate the information to all frontline police officers. Concurrently, we checked with the parents and learned that their daughter had a location-sharing app activated on her phone. We tracked to her last-known location within the hotel premises where we eventually found her. [To be continued in comment section]

caption: The Police Tactical Unit (PTU) is a strategic force under the Special Operations Command that supports the Singapore Police Force in managing public order and public security incidents. The history of the PTU dates back to the formation of the first Riot Squad in 1952, following the Maria Hertogh riots, the first post-war major riot in Singapore. This was followed by the establishment of the first Reserve Unit (RU) in 1953, which was made up of three troops of 50 regular officers, to respond to riot control and disaster management. The RU was later renamed as the Police Task Force in 1980, before eventually being renamed in 2005 to the PTU as we know of today. The PTU is a highly-trained and well-equipped outfit tasked to handle public order and public security incidents on land, offshore, and maritime environments. The unit conducts regular patrols at high footfall locations in Singapore and also supports major operations.

caption: , : Being an Emergency Response Team (ERT) officer at Bedok Police Division has been a childhood dream come true for me. I enjoy the tactical trainings, I like my job, and every day brings about something new. This is probably why I like to stay active during my off-days as well. I first signed up for the MyResponder app back in 2017, which alerts members of the public to nearby emergency cases. Being a police officer, I am trained in CPR. I thought to myself - why not put these skills to good use? Thus far, Ive been activated seven times via the app to cases where someone in my vicinity needed assistance. The first time I got activated was in 2020. I was at home when the alert of a Suspected Cardiac Arrest popped up stating that someone in the neighbouring condo unit needed assistance. I quickly rushed over and sought the help of the security guard to bring me up to the unit. We found an elderly man who had collapsed between some furniture. I had to think quick on my feet. We repositioned the man and I asked the security guard to assist me with the AED as I conducted CPR. Fortunately, the paramedics soon arrived and conveyed him to the hospital. The most recent incident happened earlier in April this year. Since this wasnt my first activation, I already had a personal process set in place to ensure I was fully prepared to assist when on the scene: (i) receive the alert, (ii) check for the nearest AED then (iii) head to the location. When I arrived, a crowd of onlookers had already formed. I saw a lady attempting to do CPR on an elderly man with the assistance of an SCDF operator on the phone. I quickly took over from the lady until paramedics arrived. I then found out that the elderly mans bicycle was still at the scene. With the help of a neighbour, we returned the bicycle to his unit where we also informed his daughter on what had happened. [To be continued in comment section]

I quickly took over from the lady until paramedics arrived. I then found out that the elderly man's bicycle was still at the scene. With the help of a neighbour, we returned the bicycle to his unit where we also informed his daughter on what had happened. [To be continued in comment section]

caption: , : Being an Emergency Response Team (ERT) officer at Bedok Police Division has been a childhood dream come true for me. I enjoy the tactical trainings, I like my job, and every day brings about something new. This is probably why I like to stay active during my off-days as well. I first signed up for the MyResponder app back in 2017, which alerts members of the public to nearby emergency cases. Being a police officer, I am trained in CPR. I thought to myself - why not put these skills to good use? Thus far, Ive been activated seven times via the app to cases where someone in my vicinity needed assistance. The first time I got activated was in 2020. I was at home when the alert of a Suspected Cardiac Arrest popped up stating that someone in the neighbouring condo unit needed assistance. I quickly rushed over and sought the help of the security guard to bring me up to the unit. We found an elderly man who had collapsed between some furniture. I had to think quick on my feet. We repositioned the man and I asked the security guard to assist me with the AED as I conducted CPR. Fortunately, the paramedics soon arrived and conveyed him to the hospital. The most recent incident happened earlier in April this year. Since this wasnt my first activation, I already had a personal process set in place to ensure I was fully prepared to assist when on the scene: (i) receive the alert, (ii) check for the nearest AED then (iii) head to the location. When I arrived, a crowd of onlookers had already formed. I saw a lady attempting to do CPR on an elderly man with the assistance of an SCDF operator on the phone. I quickly took over from the lady until paramedics arrived. I then found out that the elderly mans bicycle was still at the scene. With the help of a neighbour, we returned the bicycle to his unit where we also informed his daughter on what had happened. [To be continued in comment section]
