caption: In the 1930s, the Mobile Police Patrolmen were a familiar sight in the streets of pre-war Singapore. Clad in their white uniform and black boots, these officers rode their Birmingham Small Arms (BSA) Company motorcycles - one of the first motorcycles commissioned for the Traffic Police (TP) of yesteryear.As Singapore's roads evolved, so did our TP - TP patrol officers now use the BMW R 1250RT motorcycles for patrols and to respond to incidents. Packed with safety features such as the Anti-lock Braking System and traction control, our TP officers are now much better equipped to conduct their traffic enforcements safely and effectively.policeheritage
cleaned_caption: In the 1930s, the Mobile Police Patrolmen were a familiar sight in the streets of pre-war Singapore. As Singapore's roads evolved, so did our Traffic Police - patrol officers now use the BMW R 1250RT motorcycles for patrols and to respond to incidents. Packed with safety features such as the Anti-lock Braking System and traction control, our Traffic Police officers are now much better equipped to conduct their traffic enforcements safely and effectively.

caption: , : & - . SI Kelly Goh (K): I was considering my career choices when I was younger and I recall my classmate saying to me, Come to the sea, its very fun. Who knew that I would end up spending 18 years as a PCG officer. (laughs) SSS Nur Haqim (H): Five years ago, I was a GRF officer at Changi NPC and the switch from land to sea was interesting! I made the switch as I wanted to learn about seamanship and pick up new skills. K: This incident happened on 11 July last year. It was around 1pm in the afternoon, and we were out performing sea patrol. The sea-state was choppy with strong winds. H: Yes, the weather was bad. We received an alert regarding a boat that had capsized somewhere along the sea off East Coast Park and we proceeded to the scene immediately. K: From afar, we sighted two men in the water holding on to the sides of a capsized sailboat. Thankfully, they had lifejackets on. H: The men were exhausted from being in the water and multiple attempts of righting their sailboat. We helped them onboard our craft and found out that they lost control of their sailboat on their way to the jetty when the weather turned bad. K: We confirmed that they didnt require medical attention, and offered to assist them to flip over their capsized boat. H: It was my first time helping to overturn a vessel at sea, so in my head I was recollecting what I learnt during training. Together with my crewmates, we threw a rope to tie their vessel to ours. Then all of us pulled hard to flip the boat. K: While all of them were outside in the rain, I was inside our boat, at the helm. (laughs) H: Haha yes, but Kellys job is actually the most difficult! K: It wasnt easy controlling the boat and keeping it steady in that rough sea-state. H: Eventually, we managed to flip the boat over. The mens belongings were floating around the water, so we helped to retrieve the items for them as well.[continued]

H: It was my first time helping to overturn a vessel at sea, so in my head I was recollecting what I learnt during training. Together with my crewmates, we threw a rope to tie their vessel to ours. Then all of us pulled hard to flip the boat. K: While all of them were outside in the rain, I was inside our boat, at the helm. (laughs) H: Haha yes, but Kelly's job is actually the most difficult! K: It wasn't easy controlling the boat and keeping it steady in that rough sea-state. H: Eventually, we managed to flip the boat over. The men's belongings were floating around the water, so we helped to retrieve the items for them as well.

caption: In the 1970s, police patrol cars served predominantly as a mode of transport for officers to respond to crime scenes and to patrol the neighbourhoods. They were fitted with basic equipment such as the siren and loud hailer .Today, our police patrol cars are more than just a mode of transport. In 2020, the SPF rolled out the Next-generation Fast Response Car.Two key features of these cars include the Automated Number Plate Recognition (ANPR) system and the In-Vehicle Video Recording System (IVVRS).The ANPR system detects vehicle of interest on the move, without officers having to divert their attention from other ongoing tasks while the IVVRS provides live streaming of high-resolution video footage to the Police Operations Command Centre that allows for better sense-making and incident management. policeheritage

caption: () On 5 August 2022, SC/Sgt Afiq Aliuddin Bin Azhar and three of his colleagues were on board the train when they were approached by a student from Orchid Park Secondary School. Little did they expect to receive a post-it note from her expressing her gratitude towards the officers for serving our nation Every day, our Public Transport Security Command (TransCom) officers conduct patrols and checks at our public land transport system to safeguard us against crime. These heart-warming gestures are testament to our officers hard work and inspire us in our pursuit to keep Singapore safe and secure. singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeverydayStrongerTogether Majulah NDP2022
cleaned_caption: On 5 August 2022, SC/Sgt and three of his colleagues were on board the train when they were approached by a student from Orchid Park Secondary School. caption: , : & / . . .SGT Ayden Goh (A): This incident happened on 15 Aug 2021. Nick and I overheard a member of the public informing our counter officer that she saw an elderly man at one of the blocks nearby who looked like he needed some assistance.V/SGT Nick Koh (N): Ayden and I quickly headed over to see if we could offer help.A: We soon found the elderly man sitting on a bench under one of the blocks. He looked to be in his seventies and seemed a little short of breath. He was unable to tell us his address.N: We learnt that he had lodged a report regarding his missing phone at the NPC earlier, so we checked with our counter officer for his address and details of his next-of-kin.A: We helped him up but he suddenly lost consciousness and collapsed on me. I quickly grabbed hold of him before he hit the floor.N: We checked for his pulse. There was no breathing. We had to act fast and I immediately initiated CPR on him. Although this was my first time doing so, I was surprised that I did not have any fear and my first-aid training had kicked in allowing me to act instantly.A: While Nick was attending to the man, I called for an ambulance and relayed the information to the rest of my team. I then rushed to grab the nearest AED and set it up as Nick continued to do the compressions.N: I knew that these first few minutes were extremely crucial and my thoughts were just focused on saving the man.A: Yes, the reality struck me that his life was at stake.N: Paramedics soon arrived but we were still unable to resuscitate him before he was conveyed to the hospital.A: I felt quite affected by the whole incident. I found myself asking whether there was anything else we could have done more or have acted sooner. Nick came to assure me that we did the best we could.[continued]

caption: The Police Coast Guard (PCG), formerly known as the Marine Police, has come a long way from its humble beginnings to become a professional and modern unit that safeguards Singapore's territorial waters today.In 1951, 200 men were drafted to the Marine Police to operate a new fleet of boats. The majority of them had no experience in organised seamanship other than experience on fishing vessels. Throughout the rest of the year, classes were organised for officers to be qualified Steersman to operate the boat and to improve the operational effectiveness of the unit.Today, all our frontline PCG officers are trained in seamanship, navigation, boat handling and weaponry, to deter and detect criminal activities out at sea.In June 2022, PCG commissioned the 5th Generation PT Class Patrol Craft with features such as the remote weapon system, waterjet propulsion for speed manoeuvrability, and improved sensors for surveillance and navigation. The addition of these new boats further enhanced PCGs crime-fighting capabilities at the frontline.policeheritage
cleaned_caption: The Police Coast Guard (PCG), formerly known as the Marine Police, has come a long way from its humble beginnings to become a professional and modern unit that safeguards Singapore's territorial waters today. In 1951, 200 men were drafted to the Marine Police to operate a new fleet of boats. The majority of them had no experience in organised seamanship other than experience on fishing vessels. Throughout the rest of the year, classes were organised for officers to be qualified Steersman to operate the boat and to improve the operational effectiveness of the unit. Today, all our frontline PCG officers are trained in seamanship, navigation, boat handling and weaponry, to deter and detect criminal activities out at sea. In June 2022, PCG commissioned the 5th Generation PT Class Patrol Craft with features such as the remote weapon system, waterjet propulsion for speed manoeuvrability, and improved sensors for surveillance and navigation. The addition of these new boats further enhanced PCG's crime-fighting capabilities at the frontline. #policeheritage

caption: , : & . . SGT Nur Fadilah (N): It was about 10pm on 22 June when we received a call telling us that a unit at Marsiling Crescent was on fire. Franco was my patrol partner that night. Hes a full-time Police National Serviceman who joined the Woodlands West NPC just two months ago. SC Franco Kam (F): Being a GRF officer has been an eye-opening experience! I felt quite assured being with Fadilah as we headed to the scene. Shes been in the Force for over 13 years. N: As we entered the carpark, we saw a group of residents had already gathered at the foot of the block. I looked up and saw thick black smoke coming out from the unit on the second floor. N: When they saw our vehicle, the residents started waving at us to get our attention. One of the residents urgently told us that there were people still trapped in the unit. We had to act fast. F: It was shocking to see that the smoke had reached all the way down to the first floor lift landing. With a fire extinguisher in hand, I ran up the stairwell together with Fadilah. N: Outside the unit, the smoke was tremendously thick and we had poor visibility. Franco started calling out Is there anyone inside?. That was when we heard cries coming from the living room. F: We didnt think twice. Both of us immediately dashed into the burning unit towards the sound of the crying child. I searched around with my torchlight and saw a small boy curled up on the living room floor. N: I remembered thinking how much the boy reminded me of my three-year-old son at home and how important it was to get him to safety. He grabbed on to me tightly as I quickly carried him on my shoulders and ran out of the house. [continued]

caption: Deputy Superintendent of Police (DSP) Paul Lim is a father of two and an NS division commander in the Protective Security Command (ProCom). He shares with us his perspectives playing both roles: Being an NS leader is very much like being a father. I lead by example, set the right tone and set the right processes. This isn't very much different from being a father at home to my children. I have a 4-year-old son and a 2-year-old daughter. I'm always the happiest when spending time with them and making them laugh. But I do treat my NSmen like family, and I make sure I do my best to interact with every single one of them and know them personally. Some of them just want to be recognised, and being recognised by their supervisor gives them a lot of pride, so they feel very accomplished when they come back for reservist duties at ProCom. I have always approached the roles of being a father and an NS leader with the same positive attitude and enthusiasm, so I don't find it a problem to juggle both roles. In fact, my children get very excited whenever they see me in uniform!When asked on what makes him proud, DSP Paul said: Seeing my children grow up with the right values and attitudes, thinking on their feet and respecting people around them. This is very much like leading an NS division as well - when officers improve and show that they are motivated and know what to do in challenging situations, that makes me proud that I am working with such capable officers in ProCom. DSP Paul has some final words as advice: Treasure your wives and partners! They will be the ones holding the fort at home when you're on duty. Give them a nice treat whenever you can and they will appreciate it.Happy Father's Day to all the amazing and dedicated fathers out there! HappyFathersDayNS55singaporepoliceforce

caption: 'Justice Is Done 2' was written in the shadow of the COVID-19 pandemic, which has upended the world in unimaginable ways. Overnight, many countries went into lockdown in a bid to stem the spread of the virus. Normal life came to a standstill while the death toll soared. This enormous loss is a reminder that every life that has been cut short is precious. And this is what motivates our Police officers in their relentless drive to seek justice for victims of crime.'Justice Is Done 2' explores how investigators solved some of the most intractable murder cases of our time. But as much as the book highlights their efforts, it also honours the unsung heroescrime scene specialists and forensic scientistswho had toiled behind the scenes to put the cuffs on the perpetrators.Download a digital copy of the book (PDF/8.01 MB) via link in bio.JusticeIsDonesingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday
cleaned_caption: 'Justice Is Done 2' was written in the shadow of the COVID-19 pandemic, which has upended the world in unimaginable ways. Overnight, many countries went into lockdown in a bid to stem the spread of the virus. Normal life came to a standstill while the death toll soared. This enormous loss is a reminder that every life that has been cut short is precious. And this is what motivates our Police officers in their relentless drive to seek justice for victims of crime. 'Justice Is Done 2' explores how investigators solved some of the most intractable murder cases of our time. But as much as the book highlights their efforts, it also honours the unsung heroes—crime scene specialists and forensic scientists—who had toiled behind the scenes to put the cuffs on the perpetrators. Download a digital copy of the book (PDF/8.01 MB) via link in bio. #JusticeIsDone #SingaporePoliceForce #SafeguardingEveryday

caption: In this line of duty, you can expect some risks on the job. Ive been in the Traffic Police for about eight years. My father was a TP officer too, so when he first learned that I joined, he was a little worried for my safety. I was undeterred though, because Ive always felt the need to serve in the force. It was about 9pm on 17 Nov 2017. I was out on patrol and on my way back to TP HQ. I was riding along Bedok Reservoir Road when I spotted a driver in a white Maserati car who wasnt wearing a seatbelt. I signalled for the car to stop a few times but he wasnt complying. My gut feeling told me something felt a bit off. The car only came to a stop due to the red traffic light ahead. I then parked my motorcycle ahead of his vehicle and approached the driver. The drivers window was wound down. I directed for him to reverse his vehicle nearer to the bus bay behind. However the moment the traffic lights turned green, he abruptly swerved to the right and accelerated his car. I was caught by surprise and since I was standing near the drivers window, my jacket got caught at the cars window frame. The vehicle continued to speed up with my arm still dangling from the window. Everything happened so quickly. I was dragged for about 124 meters before I managed to free myself. As I lay injured on the road, a few bystanders came to my aid. Paramedics arrived soon after. I was given 20 days medical leave for injuries to my knee, neck and back. The driver was eventually charged in court. After the incident, I did feel a bit down and wondered if I could continue to work due to my injuries. I honestly enjoy my job and would very much like to resume patrolling if I am certified fit to do so. To my relief and after taking a year to recover from my injuries, Im now back on the road. I count myself blessed to have the support from my wife and colleagues. As a traffic patrol officer, even the most routine traffic stop may result in rather unexpected outcome. But this doesnt deter me from doing what I love. In fact, I feel its made me a better patrol officer today.mydutymycallingsingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

caption: Deputy Superintendent of Police (DSP) Khamisah, a mother of three, is a Chief Investigation Officer at Jurong Police Division. Her son, SC Muhamad Fares Aw, is currently serving his National Service at the Special Operations Command asan Assistant Trainer.DSP Khamisah recounted the early stages of her motherhoodwhiletrying to balance her roles as a mother and a police officer. It was challenging to balance work demands and spending quality time with the children. She also recalled those days fondly in which she had to get her colleagues to babysit Fares while she settled urgent work matters.However, during her off days, she made sure that she would bring her children for outings or spend time with them at home."I watched him (Fares) grow from a baby to a toddler, a teenager and now, a police officer! It is amazing and I am proud that he is serving the nation as a police officer!"SC Muhamad Fares used to think that policing was an easy job due to his mother's jovial personality. He learnt otherwise after being enlisted intheSPF. This Mother's Day, he would like to share these heartfelt thoughts to his mother:"Having gone through trainings and policing work, I realised the challenging demands and expectations of a police officer. I understand that it must not have been easy for my mother to carve out a successful policing career and at the same time, be a good mother to my siblings andme. I want to let her know that I have the utmost respect for her and I feel so lucky to have her as my mother. I love you, Ma!".Happy Mother's Day to all the amazing and noble mothers out there!happymothersdaysafeguardingeverydaysingaporepoliceday
cleaned_caption: Deputy Superintendent of Police (DSP) Khamisah, a Chief Investigation Officer at Jurong Police Division, recounted the early stages of her motherhood while trying to balance her roles as a mother and a police officer. It was challenging to balance work demands and spending quality time with the children. She also recalled those days fondly in which she had to get her colleagues to babysit her son while she settled urgent work matters. However, during her off days, she made sure that she would bring her children for outings or spend time with them at home. "I watched him grow from a baby to a toddler, a teenager and now, a police officer! It is amazing and I am proud that he is serving the nation as a police officer!" Her son used to think that policing was an easy job due to her jovial personality. He learnt otherwise after being enlisted in the Singapore Police Force (SPF). This Mother's Day, he would like to share these heartfelt thoughts to his mother: "Having gone through training and policing work, I realised the challenging demands and expectations of a police officer. I understand that it must not have been easy for my mother to carve out a successful policing career and at the same time, be a good mother to my siblings and me. I want to let her know that I have the utmost respect for her and I feel so lucky to have her as my mother. I love you, Ma!" Happy Mother's Day to all the amazing and noble mothers out there! #happymothersdaysafeguardingeverydaysingaporepoliceday

caption: , : , / -, Wei Jie (W): Usually when new officers first join the team, it can be quite suay (unlucky). Unsurprisingly, it was Amrus first ever shift with us.K-Ron (K) and Amru (A): (laughs)K: When we received the call on 16 April at about 6pm, I was expecting a small fire usually those caused by unattended cooking - since Ive attended to those before. I only realised that wasnt the case when we turned into the street and saw the thick black smoke rising from a distance.A: A crowd had already gathered in front of the landed unit. At this point I was trying hard to recall what I learnt back in TraCom (Training Command) and to apply them at the scene. Im still so new, but I understood the basics of teamwork and looking out for each other.K: Once we parked, I grabbed a fire extinguisher from the car boot and the three of us sprinted into the house. The occupants were on the ground floor, and they pointed upwards saying that their Ah ma (grandmother) was still on the second floor.A: While Wei Jie and K-Ron ran upstairs, I stayed behind to reassure the family members and helped to prevent more crowd from gathering.W: I was quite shocked to learn how dark it was upstairs due to the density of the smoke.K: Yes, we couldnt see clearly in the thick smoke and decided to stick together.W: Actually, it was so dark I didnt even realize you were standing behind me. But I could hear you.K: Yes, we started calling out Ah ma! Ah ma! on the second-floor landing. But the moment we stepped into the smoke, I immediately started coughing. We had to retreat downstairs to catch our breath.W: At this point some people might ask - why didnt we just leave it to the firefighters who were about to arrive to rescue the Ah Ma? But it just didnt feel right to not do anything, especially when you know you can do something about it. Every minute felt precious.K: Yes, we felt like we had to die-die (absolutely) find Ah Ma.(Continued)

I only realised that wasn't the case when we turned into the street and saw the thick black smoke rising from a distance. A crowd had already gathered in front of the landed unit. At this point I was trying hard to recall what I learnt back in Training Command (TraCom) and to apply them at the scene. I'm still so new, but I understood the basics of teamwork and looking out for each other. Once we parked, I grabbed a fire extinguisher from the car boot and the three of us sprinted into the house. The occupants were on the ground floor, and they pointed upwards saying that their grandmother was still on the second floor. While my colleagues ran upstairs, I stayed behind to reassure the family members and helped to prevent more crowd from gathering. I was quite shocked to learn how dark it was upstairs due to the density of the smoke. Yes, we couldn't see clearly in the thick smoke and decided to stick together. Actually, it was so dark I didn't even realize someone was standing behind me. But I could hear them. Yes, we started calling out for the grandmother on the second-floor landing. But the moment we stepped into the smoke, I immediately started coughing. We had to retreat downstairs to catch our breath. At this point some people might ask - why didn't we just leave it to the firefighters who were about to arrive to rescue the grandmother? But it just didn't feel right to not do anything, especially when you know you can do something about it. Every minute felt precious. Yes, we felt like we had to absolutely find the grandmother. (Continued)

caption: [ : - ] The Anti-Scam Division we know today has been expanded to form the Anti-Scam Command on 22 March 2022! With greater oversight over all scam-related investigations within the SPF and co-located industry partners, the command will focus on upstream interventions through close-knit collaboration with key partners and institutions in our continuous fight against scams. PoliceWPS2022PolicingwithaHeart

caption: Rain or shine, the work of safeguarding Singapore never stops. We hope everyone is safe and sheltered. Have a good week ahead!Photo by: Naveen Rajsingaporepoliceforce safeguardingeverydaysaferneighbourhoodsinsg
cleaned_caption: Rain or shine, the work of safeguarding Singapore never stops. We hope everyone is safe and sheltered. Have a good week ahead!

caption: The Police Psychological Services Department (PPSD) was formed in April 2021 to further develop the psychological competence of the Singapore Police Force (SPF), to enhance its operational and organisational effectiveness.Police psychologists like Mr Mohamad Zailan Salihin Bin Zaihan, conduct research in scams and crimes to help SPF officers better understand the modus operandi of the criminals and psyche of the victims, so as to develop effective victim-oriented crime prevention and care initiatives.In addition, Mr Zailan also conducts psychological training for SPF officers and provides operational support during crisis negotiation situations.

In addition, they also conduct psychological training for SPF officers and provide operational support during crisis negotiation situations.

caption: ASP Shasha (S): I remembered a light drizzle had just stopped on the night of 30 July 2021. Poh and I were driving around the Woodlands industrial area when we noticed a man in a Grab rider uniform standing at the roadside pavement. He appeared to be in pain and kept pointing to his ribcage area. We quickly parked our car to check on him. Strangely, he couldnt seem to respond properly to our questions. Thats when we learned he had a hearing disability. SSS Poh (P): We ended up communicating by typing out text messages on the phone. I remember the first thing I typed was are you injured? We learned that he was cycling while delivering food, but lost control and fell. He had some abrasions on his elbows and legs, so we asked him to lie down as we rendered some light first aid.S: Poh is the kind of officer who likes to bao ka liao (does everything) We also made a check with POCC to review the footage of the nearby PolCam to ensure he wasnt a victim of any hit-and-run accident. P: We were concerned that he might have suffered internal injuries, so we called for an ambulance. The man then gestured towards his bag to say that he still had to complete his food delivery order! I gave a call to Grab and explained the situation to them. I also gave a call to the mans next-of-kin and assured them that hes safe and will be brought to the nearby hospital. S: Then we realised - what do we do with his bicycle and the delivery? So we kept the bicycle safely locked and left a note to ensure it wouldnt be taken away. Unfortunately, we had to dispose of the food order. The ambulance soon came. After explaining to the paramedics, we bade him a safe farewell. P: A few days later, we learned that the man had turned up at the NPC to pass us a handwritten note personally addressed to SC/CPL Xie Sibin, who had also assisted us in attending to the man that day. It was quite heartwarming. S: It was nice and Im thankful for having a good team. Though I have to say that we dont do this just because were on duty. When we see someone in need, in pain or at loss its only human for us to offer help!mydutymycalling singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

Officer: We also made a check with POCC to review the footage of the nearby PolCam to ensure he wasn't a victim of any hit-and-run accident. We were concerned that he might have suffered internal injuries, so we called for an ambulance. The man then gestured towards his bag to say that he still had to complete his food delivery order! I gave a call to Grab and explained the situation to them. I also gave a call to the man's next-of-kin and assured them that he's safe and will be brought to the nearby hospital. Then we realised - what do we do with his bicycle and the delivery? So we kept the bicycle safely locked and left a note to ensure it wouldn't be taken away. Unfortunately, we had to dispose of the food order. The ambulance soon came. After explaining to the paramedics, we bade him a safe farewell. A few days later, we learned that the man had turned up at the NPC to pass us a handwritten note personally addressed to an officer who had also assisted us in attending to the man that day. It was quite heartwarming. It was nice and I'm thankful for having a good team. Though I have to say that we don't do this just because we're on duty. When we see someone in need, in pain or at loss it's only human for us to offer help! #mydutymycalling #singaporepoliceforce #safeguardingeveryday

P: A few days later, we learned that the man had turned up at the NPC to pass us a handwritten note personally addressed to SC/CPL Xie Sibin, who had also assisted us in attending to the man that day. It was quite heartwarming. S: It was nice and Im thankful for having a good team. Though I have to say that we dont do this just because were on duty. When we see someone in need, in pain or at loss its only human for us to offer help!mydutymycalling singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday
cleaned_caption: ASP: I remembered a light drizzle had just stopped on the night of 30 July 2021. My colleague and I were driving around the Woodlands industrial area when we noticed a man in a Grab rider uniform standing at the roadside pavement. He appeared to be in pain and kept pointing to his ribcage area. We quickly parked our car to check on him. Strangely, he couldn't seem to respond properly to our questions. That's when we learned he had a hearing disability. We ended up communicating by typing out text messages on the phone. I remember the first thing I typed was "are you injured?" We learned that he was cycling while delivering food but lost control and fell. He had some abrasions on his elbows and legs, so we asked him to lie down as we rendered some light first aid. My colleague is the kind of officer who likes to bao ka liao (does everything). We also made a check with POCC to review the footage of the nearby PolCam to ensure he wasn't a victim of any hit-and-run accident. We were concerned that he might have suffered internal injuries, so we called for an ambulance. The man then gestured towards his bag to say that he still had to complete his food delivery order! I gave a call to Grab and explained the situation to them. I also called the man's next-of-kin and assured them that he's safe and will be brought to the nearby hospital. Then we realized - what do we do with his bicycle and the delivery? So we kept the bicycle safely locked and left a note to ensure it wouldn't be taken away. Unfortunately, we had to dispose of the food order. The ambulance soon came. After explaining to the paramedics, we bade him a safe farewell. A few days later, we learned that the man had turned up at the NPC to pass us a handwritten note personally addressed to a senior officer, who had also assisted us in attending to the man that day. It was quite heartwarming. It was nice and I'm thankful for having a good team. Though I have to say that we don't do this just because we're on duty. When we see someone in need, in pain, or at a loss, it's only human for us to offer help! #mydutymycalling #singaporepoliceforce #safeguardingeveryday

caption: , : -Being a police officer makes me feel as though Im always in uniform. Like Im in a state of mind where Im constantly being vigilant. I think its a good thing.That day on 27 Feb 2021, my two friends and I were at the hotel swimming pool celebrating one of our birthdays. I noticed a few kids were playing at the other end of the pool with the adults. I have a young nephew at home, so I tend to be more aware when kids are involved. I then noticed at the corner of my eye something pink at the bottom of the pool. I waded closer and it only dawned on me when I saw a little girls motionless arms and legs. Without second thoughts, I dived into the pool to reach out to the girl, and one of the adults helped pull her out of the water. As the family members dialled for an ambulance, I attempted to do CPR on her. I remembered myself shaking when doing the compressions but I quickly composed myself as I had to stay absolutely focused on the task. To my relief, she eventually expelled out the water from her mouth and started breathing. The CPR compressions only lasted a minute but that moment felt like a whole millennia to me and her family members.The ambulance arrived shortly to bring the girl to the hospital. After everyone left, I decided to stay and sit on the bench near the swimming pool alone. I found myself thinking what could have happened if the girl didnt make it or if shell be okay. It was a mixture of relief and concern.When this incident was published on social media, the mother reached out to me. She expressed her thanks and said that her girl wanted to give me a token of gratitude. I appreciated the gesture but turned down her kind offer as I was just happy to hear that her daughter was safe and sound. Thats all I really needed.Im thankful for doing the things I get to do on a daily basis as an officer, to be able to make a difference in someones life with my little contributions. Honestly, I think anyone would have done what I did. All it takes is some courage something I believe everyone has in them.mydutymycallingsingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday
cleaned_caption: Being a police officer makes me feel as though I'm always in uniform. Like I'm in a state of mind where I'm constantly being vigilant. I think it's a good thing. That day on 27 Feb 2021, my friends and I were at the hotel swimming pool celebrating one of our birthdays. I noticed a few kids were playing at the other end of the pool with the adults. I have a young nephew at home, so I tend to be more aware when kids are involved. I then noticed at the corner of my eye something pink at the bottom of the pool. I waded closer and it only dawned on me when I saw a little girl's motionless arms and legs. Without second thoughts, I dived into the pool to reach out to the girl, and one of the adults helped pull her out of the water. As the family members dialed for an ambulance, I attempted to do CPR on her. I remembered myself shaking when doing the compressions but I quickly composed myself as I had to stay absolutely focused on the task. To my relief, she eventually expelled out the water from her mouth and started breathing. The CPR compressions only lasted a minute but that moment felt like a whole millennia to me and her family members. The ambulance arrived shortly to bring the girl to the hospital. After everyone left, I decided to stay and sit on the bench near the swimming pool alone. I found myself thinking what could have happened if the girl didn't make it or if she'll be okay. It was a mixture of relief and concern. When this incident was published on social media, the mother reached out to me. She expressed her thanks and said that her girl wanted to give me a token of gratitude. I appreciated the gesture but turned down her kind offer as I was just happy to hear that her daughter was safe and sound. That's all I really needed. I'm thankful for doing the things I get to do on a daily basis as an officer, to be able to make a difference in someone's life with my little contributions. Honestly, I think anyone would have done what I did. All it takes is some courage - something I believe everyone has in them. #mydutymycalling #singaporepoliceforce #safeguardingeveryday

caption: Today is Total Defence Day.All of us play important roles in building a strong, secure and cohesive nation. Here are what Sergeant (V) Chua Cai Yun Yvonne and National Service Probationary Inspector (NSPI) Muhammad Irsyad Bin Abdul Jalil have to say about Total Defence.SGT (V) Yvonne Chua: "Always stay alert and be vigilant about your surroundings. Even though Singapore is very safe, things can always happen when you least expect it.NSPI Muhammad Irsyad Bin Abdul Jalil: "My officers and I are armed with mid-range firearms with higher firepower during deployments, in readiness to respond to public security-related and counter-terrorism incidents. During major security events, we will work tirelessly to ensure the safety and security of the events.WeAreTotalDefencesingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

Even though Singapore is very safe, things can always happen when you least expect it.NSPI Muhammad Irsyad Bin Abdul Jalil: "My officers and I are armed with mid-range firearms with higher firepower during deployments, in readiness to respond to public security-related and counter-terrorism incidents. During major security events, we will work tirelessly to ensure the safety and security of the events.WeAreTotalDefencesingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

caption: Police Heritage Story Volunteering with Polices Neighbourhood Watch ZoneThe Neighbourhood Watch Scheme (NWS) was one of the SPFs first community crime prevention initiatives. It was launched in 1981 to encourage neighbours in public housing estates to band together as Neighbourhood Watch Groups (NWGs) and look out for each others person and property.Since 1997, NWGs have been reorganised into Neighbourhood Watch Zones (NWZs) formed under the Residents Committees (RCs) or Neighbourhood Committees (NCs) of the respective zones. All residents belonging to the particular RC/ NCs zone automatically become members of the NWZ, which works with their local Neighbourhood Police Centre to fight crime.A new community volunteer programme will be launched in December this year, and this watch group will come under the new programme. Keep a lookout for announcements on SPF Facebook page for more details!--tuesdayssaferneighbourhoodsinsgsgpolicevolunteersSPFCommunityWatchSchemeSPFOurActionsCountFind out what other exciting opportunity awaits when you volunteer with the Police today: (Link in bio)--Photo: A 1987 crime prevention poster encouraging residents participation in NWGs.
cleaned_caption: Police Heritage Story Volunteering with Police's Neighbourhood Watch Zone. The Neighbourhood Watch Scheme (NWS) was one of the SPF's first community crime prevention initiatives. It was launched in 1981 to encourage neighbours in public housing estates to band together as Neighbourhood Watch Groups (NWGs) and look out for each other's persons and property. Since 1997, NWGs have been reorganised into Neighbourhood Watch Zones (NWZs) formed under the Residents Committees (RCs) or Neighbourhood Committees (NCs) of the respective zones. All residents belonging to the particular RC/NC's zone automatically become members of the NWZ, which works with their local Neighbourhood Police Centre to fight crime. A new community volunteer programme will be launched in December this year, and this watch group will come under the new programme. Keep a lookout for announcements on SPF Facebook page for more details! -- Photo: A 1987 crime prevention poster encouraging residents' participation in NWGs.

caption: Police Heritage Story Volunteering with Polices Riders on Watch (ROW)Since 2019, our community volunteers under the Riders on Watch (ROW) scheme have partnered our Public Transport Security Command (TransCom) officers in their fight against crime on public transport services. ROW volunteers act as additional eyes and ears for TransCom during their commute on public transport nodes, by keeping watch for suspicious persons or activities and providing valuable information to the Police when needed. We thank all our volunteers for keeping our public transport networks safe!A new community volunteer programme will be launched in December this year, and this watch group will come under the new programme. Keep a lookout for announcements on SPF Facebook page for more details!--tuesdayssaferneighbourhoodsinsgsgpolicevolunteersSPFCommunityWatchSchemeSPFOurActionsCountFind out what other exciting opportunity awaits when you volunteer with the Police today: (Link in bio)--Photo: An ROW post card.

caption: Police Heritage Story Volunteering with Polices Vehicles on Watch (VOW)You may have noticed these signages on Vehicles on Watch (VOW) at your local carparks. Since 2015, the SPF has called upon residents who own in-vehicle cameras to keep the vehicles in their neighbourhood safe. Participating residents under the VOW assist the Police in investigations by providing footage from their in-vehicle cameras. VOW car parks are identified by a sign installed at the car park entrance. Lets continue to keep our carparks safe!A new community volunteer programme will be launched in December this year, and this watch group will come under the new programme. Keep a lookout for announcements on SPF Facebook page for more details!--tuesdayssaferneighbourhoodsinsgsgpolicevolunteersSPFCommunityWatchSchemeSPFOurActionsCountFind out what other exciting opportunity awaits when you volunteer with the Police today: (Link in bio) --Photo: A VOW sign by a Neighbourhood Police Centre.

caption: Police Heritage Story Volunteering with Police as a Citizens on Patrol (COP) MemberThe Citizens on Patrol (COP) volunteer scheme was launched in 1999 to engage the community to patrol their neighbourhoods, alert the police to suspicious activities or characters, and share crime prevention knowledge with residents. Since 2019, COP members have been issued a standard vest and COP identification card while on patrol.COP members have been valuable partners to the SPF over the years, and their vigilance have enabled crimes such as thefts and loanshark activities, to be solved. We salute our COP volunteers for keeping their neighbourhoods safe!Sign up at this link if you are interested to volunteer: out what other exciting opportunity awaits when you volunteer with the Police today: (Link in bio)Hint: A new community volunteer programme will be launched in December this year. Keep a lookout for announcements on SPF Facebook!--Photo: COP members sharing crime prevention knowledge with residents.
cleaned_caption: Police Heritage Story Volunteering with Police as a Citizens on Patrol (COP) Member. The Citizens on Patrol (COP) volunteer scheme was launched in 1999 to engage the community to patrol their neighbourhoods, alert the police to suspicious activities or characters, and share crime prevention knowledge with residents. Since 2019, COP members have been issued a standard vest and COP identification card while on patrol. COP members have been valuable partners to the SPF over the years, and their vigilance has enabled crimes such as thefts and loanshark activities to be solved. We salute our COP volunteers for keeping their neighbourhoods safe! A new community volunteer programme will be launched in December this year. Keep a lookout for announcements on SPF Facebook! --Photo: COP members sharing crime prevention knowledge with residents.

caption: Police Heritage Story Volunteering with Police as a Volunteer Special Constabulary (Community) OfficerThe Volunteer Special Constabulary (VSC) (Community) vocation was launched in 2018 to create more opportunities for the public to join the VSC programme. The vocation has a shorter training duration and officers are required to perform unarmed police duties. VSC (Community) officers will be posted to one of the 7 Police Land Divisions or selected specialist and line units, and are required to serve a minimum of 8 hours of duty per month.Sign up at this link if you are interested to volunteer: out what other exciting opportunity awaits when you volunteer with the Police today: (Link in bio)Hint: A new community volunteer programme will be launched in December this year. Keep a lookout for announcements on SPF Facebook!--Photo: VSC (Community) officers sharing crime prevention advisories with residents. (Source: Singapore Press Holdings Limited. Permission required for reproduction.)
cleaned_caption:
Police Heritage Story Volunteering with Police as a Volunteer Special Constabulary (Community) Officer. The Volunteer Special Constabulary (VSC) (Community) vocation was launched in 2018 to create more opportunities for the public to join the VSC programme. The vocation has a shorter training duration and officers are required to perform unarmed police duties. VSC (Community) officers will be posted to one of the 7 Police Land Divisions or selected specialist and line units, and are required to serve a minimum of 8 hours of duty per month. 

Hint: A new community volunteer programme will be launched in December this year. Keep a lookout for announcements on SPF Facebook! 

--Photo: VSC (Community) officers sharing crime prevention advisories with residents. (Source: Singapore Press Holdings Limited. Permission required for reproduction.)

caption: Police Heritage Story Volunteering with Police as a Volunteer Special Constabulary Officer2021 marks the 75th anniversary of the Volunteer Special Constabulary (VSC), which was formed in 1946 to augment the regular ranks in the Singapore Police Force (SPF). In the aftermath of World War II, manpower was badly needed to restore law and order in Singapore. About 100 men responded to the call and joined as the first VSC officers. Since then, thousands have followed in their footsteps and the VSC stands at more than 1,200 strong today.VSC officers are vested with the powers of a police officer and contribute significantly to keeping Singapore safe. We salute all VSC officers, past and present, for their service!Sign up at this link if you are interested to volunteer as a VSC: out what other exciting opportunity awaits when you volunteer with the Police today: (Link in bio)Hint: A new community volunteer programme will be launched in December this year. Keep a lookout for announcements on SPF Facebook!--Photo: VSC Officers being sworn in at a police station in Pasir Panjang, 1949. (Source: Singapore Press Holdings Limited. Permission required for reproduction.)
cleaned_caption: Police Heritage Story Volunteering with Police as a Volunteer Special Constabulary Officer. 2021 marks the 75th anniversary of the Volunteer Special Constabulary (VSC), which was formed in 1946 to augment the regular ranks in the Singapore Police Force (SPF). In the aftermath of World War II, manpower was badly needed to restore law and order in Singapore. About 100 men responded to the call and joined as the first VSC officers. Since then, thousands have followed in their footsteps and the VSC stands at more than 1,200 strong today. VSC officers are vested with the powers of a police officer and contribute significantly to keeping Singapore safe. We salute all VSC officers, past and present, for their service! Sign up at this link if you are interested to volunteer as a VSC: out what other exciting opportunities await when you volunteer with the Police today: (Link in bio). Hint: A new community volunteer programme will be launched in December this year. Keep a lookout for announcements on SPF Facebook! -- Photo: VSC Officers being sworn in at a police station in Pasir Panjang, 1949. (Source: Singapore Press Holdings Limited. Permission required for reproduction.)

caption: () ! The VSC scheme was introduced on 1 October 1946 to augment the regular ranks in the Singapore Police Force (SPF) after World War II, when manpower was badly needed to restore law and order in Singapore.Throughout the years, VSC officers played an integral role serving alongside their regular and PNS counterparts in preventing, deterring and detecting crime.We thank all volunteers, past and present, for your contributions in keeping Singapore safe and secure.If you are interested in finding out more about the different volunteer schemes, click on the link in bio.safeguardingeverydaysingaporepoliceforcesgpolicevolunteers

Throughout the years, VSC officers played an integral role serving alongside their regular and PNS counterparts in preventing, deterring and detecting crime. We thank all volunteers, past and present, for your contributions in keeping Singapore safe and secure. caption: This is not a futuristic phone booth but SPF's very own Police Beacon! The Police Beacon was deployed at Punggol Waterway Park Connector and Sengkang Riverside Park Connector for trial in December 2020. Its built-in functions allow the public to connect with the Police directly in times of need and enhances security in secluded spaces.Have you seen or used the Police Beacon before? Share your experience with us below!Have a great weekend everyone!Photo by: Naveen Rajsingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeverydaysaferneighbourhoodsinsg
cleaned_caption: This is not a futuristic phone booth but SPF's very own Police Beacon! The Police Beacon was deployed at Punggol Waterway Park Connector and Sengkang Riverside Park Connector for trial in December 2020. caption: Some of you may have heard that one of our Gurkha Contingent (GC) officers, Subas Gurung, will be participating in the Pocari Sweat Run on 10 Oct 2021.The Singapore Police Force supports officers like Subas, who train hard every day to keep operationally fit, in order to safeguard Singapore and her residents. Subas is known to be one of the fittest officers in the GC. He last recorded a 6 minutes 58 seconds timing for his 2.4km run during his IPPT in July 2021, after doing 59 push-ups and 60 sit-ups, finishing with a perfect score.As an avid runner, Subas registered for the run on 3 Sep 2021 on his own accord, and is looking to join the race not to best any runner, but merely to challenge himself and his personal record. He is but one of the many GC officers who push themselves to their limit on a regular basis, training hard so that they can execute demanding duties well in a variety of police operations.The Singapore Police Force is proud to have officers like Subas. Whatever the results may be on 10 Oct 2021, it is the spirit of sportsmanship, steadfastness and service to the nation which Subas embodies, that matters most.We will cheer for Subas as well as the many other participating runners from all walks of life at the upcoming run!SingaporePoliceForce SafeguardingEverydayPhoto 1: GC officer Subas Gurung (centre) representing SPF in the World Police & Fire Games in 2019Photo 2: Gurkha Contingent officers are deployed for a variety of operational roles, for example, to ensure security at the recent visit to Singapore by the Vice President of the United States (22-24 August 2021).
cleaned_caption:
Some of you may have heard that one of our Gurkha Contingent (GC) officers will be participating in the Pocari Sweat Run on 10 Oct 2021. The Singapore Police Force supports officers who train hard every day to keep operationally fit, in order to safeguard Singapore and her residents. This officer is known to be one of the fittest in the GC, having recorded a 6 minutes 58 seconds timing for a 2.4km run during his IPPT in July 2021, after doing 59 push-ups and 60 sit-ups, finishing with a perfect score. As an avid runner, he registered for the run on 3 Sep 2021 on his own accord, and is looking to join the race not to best any runner, but merely to challenge himself and his personal record. He is but one of the many GC officers who push themselves to their limit on a regular basis, training hard so that they can execute demanding duties well in a variety of police operations. The Singapore Police Force is proud to have such officers. Whatever the results may be on 10 Oct 2021, it is the spirit of sportsmanship, steadfastness and service to the nation which these officers embody that matters most. We will cheer for them as well as the many other participating runners from all walks of life at the upcoming run!

Photo 1: GC officer representing SPF in the World Police & Fire Games in 2019. Photo 2: Gurkha Contingent officers are deployed for a variety of operational roles, for example, to ensure security at the recent visit to Singapore by the Vice President of the United States (22-24 August 2021).

caption: In the first half of 2021, loan scams became the top scam type while the number of job scam cases reported jumped more than sixteen-fold compared to the same period in 2020.Principal Psychologist Ms Carolyn Misir from the Police Psychological Services Department shared how scammers tend to take advantage of prevailing societal conditions and change their tactics accordingly, using a variety of persuasion techniques and cognitive biases to induce victims into falling prey to scams.Fighting scams is a community effort. Beware of scams and stay well-informed! Your vigilance is our very first line of defence.spotthesignssingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday
cleaned_caption: In the first half of 2021, loan scams became the top scam type while the number of job scam cases reported jumped more than sixteen-fold compared to the same period in 2020. Principal Psychologist from the Police Psychological Services Department shared how scammers tend to take advantage of prevailing societal conditions and change their tactics accordingly, using a variety of persuasion techniques and cognitive biases to induce victims into falling prey to scams. Fighting scams is a community effort. Beware of scams and stay well-informed! Your vigilance is our very first line of defence. #spotthesigns #singaporepoliceforce #safeguardingeveryday

caption: While scams remain a concern, the Police have been doubling efforts in the fight against scams through various initiatives with multiple stakeholders.Deputy Assistant Commissioner of Police Aileen Yap from the Anti-Scam Division shared the latest initiative, Project COMBAT, which utilises Robotic Process Automation to send out targeted advisories to warn potential scam victims from falling prey. This will be scalable to address new scam trends as they continue to evolve.The Police will continue to work closely with both local telcos and foreign law enforcement agencies to share information on emerging scams and cripple scam syndicates.spotthesignssingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

This will be scalable to address new scam trends as they continue to evolve. The Police will continue to work closely with both local telcos and foreign law enforcement agencies to share information on emerging scams and cripple scam syndicates. #spotthesigns #singaporepoliceforce #safeguardingeveryday

caption: <Post-Blast Investigations Finding the needle in the haystack quickly>At the post-blast scene, things can be pretty messy and uncovering the truth after an explosion can be daunting.Enter the post-blast investigators, who seek to gather and process leads quickly to identify potential culprits and stop them from causing further harm to innocent victims. All these have to be done while ensuring that the crime scene is not contaminated and that their safety are not compromised.Here are some photos showing what the investigators need to do at a post-blast scene.Photo 1: A mock-up scene after a bomb blast.Photo 2: Investigators have to don the full protective gear to protect themselves from corrosive chemicals or infectious substances, and to prevent contamination of the scene.Here, he is picking up traces of explosive substances left at the scene and analysing them using the Explosives Test Kit.This kit helps detect a wide spectrum of explosive substances or trace residues present at the scene.Photo 3: Investigator gathering traces of explosive substances and analysing them using a chemical analyser.This machine measures the amount of light energy absorbed or scattered by the unknown chemical after being excited by a laser. It is used to identify unknown chemicals both in solid and liquid forms in post-blast investigation operations.Photo 4: Investigator performing X-ray on an object suspected to be a component of an improvised explosive device using the portable X-ray system.The portable X-ray system is used to ascertain the internal contents of an object, and to determine if it is safe for the investigator to process the object.
cleaned_caption: <Post-Blast Investigations Finding the needle in the haystack quickly>At the post-blast scene, things can be pretty messy and uncovering the truth after an explosion can be daunting. Enter the post-blast investigators, who seek to gather and process leads quickly to identify potential culprits and stop them from causing further harm to innocent victims. All these have to be done while ensuring that the crime scene is not contaminated and that their safety is not compromised. Here are some photos showing what the investigators need to do at a post-blast scene. Photo 1: A mock-up scene after a bomb blast. Photo 2: Investigators have to don the full protective gear to protect themselves from corrosive chemicals or infectious substances, and to prevent contamination of the scene. Here, the investigator is picking up traces of explosive substances left at the scene and analysing them using the Explosives Test Kit. This kit helps detect a wide spectrum of explosive substances or trace residues present at the scene. Photo 3: Investigator gathering traces of explosive substances and analysing them using a chemical analyser. This machine measures the amount of light energy absorbed or scattered by the unknown chemical after being excited by a laser. It is used to identify unknown chemicals both in solid and liquid forms in post-blast investigation operations. Photo 4: Investigator performing X-ray on an object suspected to be a component of an improvised explosive device using the portable X-ray system. The portable X-ray system is used to ascertain the internal contents of an object and to determine if it is safe for the investigator to process the object.

caption: Happy Friday! Seen the VIPs Motorcade at the ceremonial parade on National Day? Heres some fun facts about it:The motorcade is a display of precision, teamwork and trust between the officers. Five Traffic Police riders and the VIPs vehicle enter the Float, travel and stop at precisely the same speed. Thereafter, in a well-trained and coordinated manner, all the riders place their left legs down at the exact same time once their vehicles come to a stop. Be sure to keep a lookout for this in the next NDP show! Have a good weekend!safeguardingeverydaysingaporepoliceforceNDP2021TogetherOurSGSpirit
cleaned_caption: Happy Friday! Seen the VIPs Motorcade at the ceremonial parade on National Day? Here are some fun facts about it: The motorcade is a display of precision, teamwork and trust between the officers. Five Traffic Police riders and the VIPs vehicle enter the Float, travel and stop at precisely the same speed. Thereafter, in a well-trained and coordinated manner, all the riders place their left legs down at the exact same time once their vehicles come to a stop. Be sure to keep a lookout for this in the next NDP show! Have a good weekend! #safeguardingeverydaysingapore #policeforce #NDP2021 #TogetherOurSGSpirit

caption: We hope you have caught the Ceremonial Parade earlier this morning. DSP Gregory Kang is the commander for the SPF Guard of Honour contingent this year, and here is what he has to say!Our Singapore Spirit is an enduring one, where many generations have worked hard in our nation building journey and passed the baton to the next generation.Every year, the National Day reminds us of how far this country has gone against the odds, and how the men and women of the Singapore Police Force will continue to play our part to keep the Singapore flag flying high, by keeping our people safe and secure.safeguardingeverydaysingaporepoliceforceNDP2021TogetherOurSGSpirit

caption: Our nations road to independence and early years were fraught with challenges, but our pioneers stood firm in adversity and overcame all odds, to build the country we call home today. We have our own set of challenges today, but with unity, resilience and determination, we will ride out the storm together. Happy birthday, Singapore! Here are some photos of the Singapore Police Force contingents participating in the Parade segment on National Day over the years since independence. caption: [ : , ]When it comes to operational duties, time is of the essence.The Automated Equipping System (AES) allows officers to withdraw and return operational equipment from smart lockers complemented by RFID and QR code technology at the start and end of their shift. This automated process removes the need for a maintenance officer thus saving time and improving efficiency at work.From 2021, an updated AES with improved design and specifications will be rolled out to all NPCs progressively.PoliceWPS2021SmarterPolicingEmpoweredCommunity

caption: [ : , ]Mimicking an operational terrain and driven by analytics, the Live Instrumentation Training System (LITS) comprises of an Instrumented Laser Engagement System and a Force-On-Robotic Target, which uses a human-like target system with a shoot-back system that can identify, track and fire at trainees.The analytics system then consolidates results of the simulated firefight and provides training data such as the number of shots hit or missed, time taken and location. This feedback allows trainees to take prompt corrective action, thus improving overall training efficacy and enhances training realism.From December 2021, the SPF, HTX (Home Team Science and Technology Agency) and Home Team Academy (HTA) will trial LITS with frontline officers who are undergoing In-Situ Reaction Team tactical training for a 3-month period at HTA. Should the trial be successful, frontline officers can look forward to the implementation of LITS for tactical training in the future.PoliceWPS2021SmarterPolicingEmpoweredCommunity
cleaned_caption: Mimicking an operational terrain and driven by analytics, the Live Instrumentation Training System (LITS) comprises of an Instrumented Laser Engagement System and a Force-On-Robotic Target, which uses a human-like target system with a shoot-back system that can identify, track and fire at trainees. The analytics system then consolidates results of the simulated firefight and provides training data such as the number of shots hit or missed, time taken and location. This feedback allows trainees to take prompt corrective action, thus improving overall training efficacy and enhancing training realism. From December 2021, the Singapore Police Force (SPF), Home Team Science and Technology Agency (HTX) and Home Team Academy (HTA) will trial LITS with frontline officers who are undergoing In-Situ Reaction Team tactical training for a 3-month period at HTA. Should the trial be successful, frontline officers can look forward to the implementation of LITS for tactical training in the future. PoliceWPS2021SmarterPolicingEmpoweredCommunity

caption: The Police would like to alert members of the public to stay vigilant against job scams. These scams may come in the form of text messages and would typically offer highly-paid job openings that can be performed from home.Learn how to spotthesigns and share this message with your family and friends.singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

caption: [SPF Workplan Seminar 2021: Smarter Policing, Empowered Community]The Mobile TASER Training Target (MTTT) uses computer vision technology to detect the landing points of taser probes on the training target, and collect training data to analyse trainees strengths and weaknesses in their deployment of the taser.This helps officers in their post-training evaluation to sharpen and enhance taser training.MTTT reduces the risk of injury during scenario-based training and is especially useful during the COVID-19 pandemic in reducing physical contact during training.From July 2021, the SPF and HTX (Home Team Science and Technology Agency) will trial customised prototypes of the MTTT with SPF frontline units for a 3-month period. Should the trial be successful, frontline officers can look forward to the implementation of MTTT for training in the future.PoliceWPS2021SmarterPolicingEmpoweredCommunity

This helps officers in their post-training evaluation to sharpen and enhance taser training. MTTT reduces the risk of injury during scenario-based training and is especially useful during the COVID-19 pandemic in reducing physical contact during training. From July 2021, the SPF and HTX (Home Team Science and Technology Agency) will trial customised prototypes of the MTTT with SPF frontline units for a 3-month period. Should the trial be successful, frontline officers can look forward to the implementation of MTTT for training in the future. PoliceWPS2021SmarterPolicingEmpoweredCommunity

caption: Doesnt he look familiar? Yes! He was the Ground Response Force Team Leader in our recent video titled Our People, Our Heartware, published on Police Day! In case you are wondering, he is indeed a police officer (and not an actor)!SUPT Shannon Lin is currently the Deputy Head of the Unlicensed Moneylending Strikeforce under the Criminal Investigation Department. At work, he leads a team of officers in solving crimes related to unlicensed moneylending.At home, he is a proud father of two lovely kids, Shania and Shane.I am proud of papa, because he catches bad guys to keep us safe, said Shania. Shania, Shannon's 6-year-old daughter, inspired by her father, wishes to become a scientist one day so that she can "make medicine to save lives just like papa".I just hope that she can grow up to be a compassionate person, said Shannon in response to the impact he wishes to leave on his daughter.Its safe to say that his hope is turning into a reality.Happy Fathers Day to all fathers who continue to inspire and motivate our next generation!Photos by: Naveen Rajsingaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday happyfathersday

caption: There is no such thing as a "Government subsidised loan package."A licensed moneylender cannot advertise loan services via cold calls or unsolicited text messages, or even on social media or online marketplace platforms. If you receive a cold call, unsolicited text message, or see a Facebook ad asking if you would like to take up a loan, please do not respond. Block and report the number to the Police via the i-witness platform.Do also share this advisory with your family and friends.
cleaned_caption: There is no such thing as a "Government subsidised loan package." A licensed moneylender cannot advertise loan services via cold calls or unsolicited text messages, or even on social media or online marketplace platforms. If you receive a cold call, unsolicited text message, or see a Facebook ad asking if you would like to take up a loan, please do not respond. Block and report the number to the Police via the i-witness platform. Do also share this advisory with your family and friends.

caption: Making illegal soccer bets online contravenes the Remote Gambling Act. Under the Act, anyone caught using remote communications and using a remote gambling service by a non-exempted operator can get fined up to $5,000, or jailed up to 6 months, or both. If you receive such SMSes, you can either provide the information to us via our i-Witness portal or call the Police Hotline at 1800-255-0000. Let's enjoy the European Football Championship and not get too carried away in the excitement!safeguardingeveryday singaporepoliceforce euro2020

caption: Before Singapore gained full internal self-governance in 1959, the Police crest was adapted from the colonial flag and comprised an inverted pall with a crown in the middle, representing the Crown Colony of Singapore. After 1959, Singapores state flag, comprising a crescent moon and five stars,was adapted into the Police crest which we recognise today. Look out for a genuine 1950s Police cap badge and more in the Frontier Town to Safest City virtual exhibition. Click the link in bio to begin your journey!(Image of Colonial Singapore Police Force cap badge courtesy of private collector) SingaporePoliceHeritagePoliceVirtualTour
cleaned_caption: Before Singapore gained full internal self-governance in 1959, the Police crest was adapted from the colonial flag and comprised an inverted pall with a crown in the middle, representing the Crown Colony of Singapore. After 1959, Singapore's state flag, comprising a crescent moon and five stars, was adapted into the Police crest which we recognise today. Look out for a genuine 1950s Police cap badge and more in the Frontier Town to Safest City virtual exhibition. Click the link in bio to begin your journey! (Image of Colonial Singapore Police Force cap badge courtesy of private collector)

caption: Police Day has been observed every 3 June since 1971. A date of special significance, 3 June 1959 was when Singapore obtained self-governance and the Police became the law enforcement agency of an elected Government. Although Police Day will be observed differently this year due to the COVID-19 pandemic, SPF officers remain unwavering in their pledge to serve the nation and carry out their duties with courage, loyalty, integrity and fairness.singaporepoliceheritage policeday2021 ---If you enjoyed this post and want to learn more about SPFs history, we invite you to visit the Frontier Town to Safest City virtual tour (see link @ bio)!---Picture 1: Minister for Home Affairs, Mr Wong Lin Ken, at the first Police Day parade in 1971. (Source: Ministry of Information and the Arts Collection, courtesy of National Archives of Singapore)Picture 2: Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Law, Mr S. Jayakumar at 1993 Police Day parade.Picture 3: Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Law, Mr K Shanmugam at 2019 Police Day parade

caption: Growing up, Sergeant Leow Su Ling watched her mother served in the Singapore Police Force (SPF) with both dedication and passion. This became a valuable inspiration and motivating factor for her to join the force, with a trusted confidante and adviser by her side through life and work.Mdm Ng Lay Hong, who joined the SPF in 1981 and retired in 2018 with the rank of Senior Station Inspector, is a proud mother of two children. She constantly reminds her daughter, Su Ling to stay humble and kind to others despite the challenges faced daily. When asked what Motherhood meant to her, she said, Being a Mother is one of the most powerful experiences that has brought a deeper meaning to my life. The days are long and you dont really get a day off from being a mother, but it gives me immense joy knowing that Ive raised two children who are contributing back to society in their own ways.Happy Mothers Day to all the wonderful and noble mothers out there!Photo by: SC Aloysious Lowsingaporepoliceforce happymothersday
cleaned_caption:
Growing up, Sergeant Leow watched her mother serve in the Singapore Police Force (SPF) with both dedication and passion. This became a valuable inspiration and motivating factor for her to join the force, with a trusted confidante and adviser by her side through life and work. She constantly reminds her daughter to stay humble and kind to others despite the challenges faced daily. When asked what Motherhood meant to her, she said, "Being a Mother is one of the most powerful experiences that has brought a deeper meaning to my life. The days are long and you don't really get a day off from being a mother, but it gives me immense joy knowing that I've raised two children who are contributing back to society in their own ways." Happy Mother's Day to all the wonderful and noble mothers out there! 
Photo by: SC Aloysious Low #singaporepoliceforce #happymothersday

caption: <Safety is Polices top priority in stand-off situations>Stand-off situations are incidents where Police are alerted after individuals locked themselves up to evade arrest or attempt suicide.Polices priority in such stand-off situations is to ensure safety of all persons involved and to resolve the situation with minimal harm to persons and property.Various Police resources such as the Ground Response Force (GRF), Crisis Negotiation Unit (CNU), Special Operations Command (SOC) are deployed to provide tactical options to deal with unpredictable circumstances.Given the high volatility of such situations, there exist great operational risks to our officers and officers do get hurt at times.When the individual involved has been restrained, the Police will also consider the condition of the individual and convey him/her to the hospital/Institute of Mental Health immediately, after assessing if they require medical assistance or treatment.Here are some photos of the re-enactment illustrating how Police deal with such situations.singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday
cleaned_caption: Safety is Police's top priority in stand-off situations. Stand-off situations are incidents where Police are alerted after individuals locked themselves up to evade arrest or attempt suicide. Police's priority in such stand-off situations is to ensure the safety of all persons involved and to resolve the situation with minimal harm to persons and property. Various Police resources such as the Ground Response Force (GRF), Crisis Negotiation Unit (CNU), and Special Operations Command (SOC) are deployed to provide tactical options to deal with unpredictable circumstances. Given the high volatility of such situations, there exist great operational risks to our officers and officers do get hurt at times. When the individual involved has been restrained, the Police will also consider the condition of the individual and convey him/her to the hospital or Institute of Mental Health immediately, after assessing if they require medical assistance or treatment. Here are some photos of the re-enactment illustrating how Police deal with such situations. #sgpoliceforce #safeguarding #everyday

caption: <Safety is Polices top priority in stand-off situations>Stand-off situations are incidents where Police are alerted after individuals locked themselves up to evade arrest or attempt suicide.Polices priority in such stand-off situations is to ensure safety of all persons involved and to resolve the situation with minimal harm to persons and property.Various Police resources such as the Ground Response Force (GRF), Crisis Negotiation Unit (CNU), Special Operations Command (SOC) are deployed to provide tactical options to deal with unpredictable circumstances.Given the high volatility of such situations, there exist great operational risks to our officers and officers do get hurt at times.When the individual involved has been restrained, the Police will also consider the condition of the individual and convey him/her to the hospital/Institute of Mental Health immediately, after assessing if they require medical assistance or treatment.Here are some photos of the re-enactment illustrating how Police deal with such situations.singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

Given the high volatility of such situations, there exist great operational risks to our officers, and officers do get hurt at times. Here are some photos of the re-enactment illustrating how Police deal with such situations. #safeguardingeveryday

caption: Meet SGT Al Asyraf Bin Azman from Nanyang NPC. caption: Did you know? The building we know today as Maxwell Chambers Suites was the former Traffic Police Headquarters for 69 years from 1930 to 1999. The building housed both offices and barracks facilities for officers and their families. It was also the site of Singapores first Driving Test Centre when driving tests were first introduced in 1941.Go on an adventure this weekend and discover nine iconic Police landmarks that played a role in safeguarding Singapore in the past! Photo: Man acquiring a driving licence from the Driving Test Centre at the Traffic Police Headquarters, 1951. (Source: Ministry of Information and the Arts Collection, courtesy of )ExplorePoliceHeritageTrailsingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

caption: Introducing the Police Beacon, a joint-development between SPF and HTX. Outfitted with CCTV cameras, sirens, blinkers, floodlights and speakers the beacons serve as a visible projection of police presence. Through the beacons, members of the public will be able to interact directly with the police, provide information and request for help. Catch the two prototypes on trial at the Punggol Waterway Park Connector and Sengkang Riverside Park Connector!Photos by: Eng Xuan Lin singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday
cleaned_caption: Introducing the Police Beacon, a joint development between SPF and HTX. Through the beacons, members of the public will be able to interact directly with the police, provide information, and request for help. Catch the two prototypes on trial at the Punggol Waterway Park Connector and Sengkang Riverside Park Connector!

caption: Recognised for their impressive strength, intelligence and sense of smell, dogs have been working alongside our officers since 1955. Not all dog breeds are suited for police work, and they are carefully selected and trained for tasks ranging from tracking criminals to detecting explosives. The first police dog in the SPF was a German Shepard named Rover, who was brought over from the UK in 1955 by his handler Chief Inspector Frank Pestana to form the nucleus of the K9 Unit. Picture: Chief Inspector Frank Pestana training with Police Dog Rover, circa. 1955.OurSPF200Heritagesafeguardingeveryday

caption: The Singapore Police Force Scholarship (SPFS) is one of the most prestigious scholarship awarded by the Public Service Commission. Meet our Singapore Police Force Scholarship scholars, Inspector Sundaram Mohan Shakthi and Inspector Sim Zheng Hao! Both of them were awarded the scholarship earlier today. Inspector Sundaram Mohan Shakthi is our second female recipient of the SPFS. When she was just 16-year-old, she learnt that the SPF is not about just catching and punishing criminals. It also focuses on rehabilitating offenders and providing social support to their family members. When asked why he wanted to join the SPF, Inspector Sim Zheng Hao said that he had a deep-rooted interest in a SPF career. His father, a former police officer, shared encounters from his policing days in 1980s since he was a child. Inspector Sim now wants to continue helping the community and give back to the society. The Singapore Police Force (SPF) Scholarship & Home Team (HT) Scholarship Award Ceremony was held virtually on Thursday, 20 August 2020. Find out more about our other scholars on SPF Facebook (link in bio).singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

caption: The Singapore Police Force commemorates Police Day on 3 June every year, since 1971. 3 June 1959 is a date of special significance as Singapore obtained self-governance on that day.In 1971, Professor Wong Lin Ken, then Minister for Home Affairs, announced the designation of 3 June as Police Day. In his speech at the opening of Police Week on 3 June 1971, he said, The Government has designated 3rd of June to be Police Day, to reaffirm the fact that the Police is a part of our society, responsible to an elected government, and the maintenance of law and order is a service to the community. This photo was taken during the first Police Day Parade on 3 June 1971. : Courtesy of National Archives of Singaporesingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday
cleaned_caption: The Singapore Police Force commemorates Police Day on 3 June every year, since 1971. 3 June 1959 is a date of special significance as Singapore obtained self-governance on that day. In 1971, the then Minister for Home Affairs announced the designation of 3 June as Police Day. In his speech at the opening of Police Week on 3 June 1971, he said, "The Government has designated 3rd of June to be Police Day, to reaffirm the fact that the Police is a part of our society, responsible to an elected government, and the maintenance of law and order is a service to the community." This photo was taken during the first Police Day Parade on 3 June 1971. : Courtesy of National Archives of Singapore
